name: United States
notes_C1: Some states, including Michigan, continue to recommend schools teach using online learning.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175154/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_C2: Whilst many states are easing restrictions, many restrictions on businesses are still in place. States do not appear to require closing of specific sectors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175601/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C3: Whilst many states are easing restrictions, many restrictions on public events are still in place.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175601/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C4: Whilst many states are easing restrictions, many restrictions on gatherings are still in place. In some areas, such as some counties in California, indoor gatherings are limited to less than 10 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175154/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_C5: Public transit functioning with some restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175601/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C6: Continued recommendations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175601/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C7: Some limitations continue.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175154/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_C8: Travel limitations continue on certain countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507222814/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Large-scale aid continues.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175601/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_E2: Government programs  are offering temporary COVID-19 assistance to pay rent, mortgages, and student loans. Food stamps and federal meal programs have also changed their rules to provide extra help during the coronavirus pandemic.    - If you're repaying a U.S. Department of Education-backed student loan, you're receiving forbearance. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, your principal and interest payments have been automatically suspended through at least September 30, 2021.     - If you’ve been affected financially by the COVID-19 pandemic and you own a single-family home with a federally backed or FHA-insured mortgage, you can request mortgage forbearance, a pause in making mortgage payments.     - If you're out of work or lost income because of the COVID-19 pandemic, you may qualify for rental assistance through your state HUD program. And a federal eviction moratorium from the CDC, extended through June 30, 2021 may help you stay in your home if you can't pay your rent.     See list of Covid-19 financial assistance from the government - https://web.archive.org/web/20210508180340/https://www.usa.gov/covid-financial-help-from-the-government
notes_H1: COVID-19 PUBLIC EDUCATION CAMPAIGN - https://web.archive.org/web/20210508180518/https://wecandothis.hhs.gov/
notes_H2: As per the CDC Testing guidelines, Test is generally available - https://web.archive.org/web/20210421021638/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/testing.html
notes_H3: Contact tracing is conducted on a statewide level, and is often further decentralized by county or local health departments or contracted out to private organizations. Not all states report their contact tracing statistics, so it is difficult to gauge the efficacy of contact tracing.     According to the CDC Covid-19 data dashboard, 8.25% of tests were positive over the past 7 days (as of April 14). As an example of contact tracing efforts, for the week of April 4, Oregon's contact tracers reached 84% of Covid-19 cases identified within a 24 hour period. Their goal is to reach 95% of cases. During the same timeframe, only 36.2% of positive cases were traced to a known source, and their goal is to trace at least 70% of cases to a known source.     Funds from the American Rescue Plan (signed into law March 11) are meant to provide technical assistance to states, municipalities, territories, and tribes to help trace and monitor the spread of Covid-19.     CDC: https://archive.vn/yvN69    Link to Plan text: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text    Link to Oregon data: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414221835/https://public.tableau.com/profile/oregon.health.authority.covid.19
notes_H6: States like Nevada require masks to be worn at all times outside the house.    State by State Policies - https://web.archive.org/web/20210508175154/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_H7: As of Monday 19th April , CDC announces that COVID-19 vaccines are available to every American over 16years who wants a shot.   CDC - https://web.archive.org/web/20210507223725/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/How-Do-I-Get-a-COVID-19-Vaccine.html

name: Alaska
notes_C1: Original note by Erin Kanzig: Beginning April 12, Juneau’s middle and high school students will be returning to school four days a week. The change expands the in-person high school schedule by one day and the middle school schedule by two days. Wednesday will remain a distance-learning day at all levels. Students can choose to continue with remote distance learning if they wish.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407192221/https://www.juneauempire.com/news/school-district-announces-expansion-of-in-person-learning/    Coding updated by Reviewer Monika Pyarali to reflect previous changes (see note on March 15)
notes_C2: Anchorage's Emergency Order 19 remains in effect as of April 7. All restaurants, bars, breweries, and night clubs can open at reduced capacity to maintain physical distancing. Indoor entertainment facilities, indoor gyms and fitness centers can also operated with reduced capacity (masks required). Establishments offering sit-down service of any kind must have visitor logs in order to assist with contact tracing. Employers must require employees to work from home if remote work is feasible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C3: Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Coded changed to 1T (from 2T) according to Attachments C and D of Anchorage Emergency Order 20 (enacted 17 April 2021). Attachment C allows for entertainment facilities to open at a capacity that allows for six feet of physical distancing and other COVID-19 related safety measures. Attachment D allows for organized sports with similar stipulations for spectators.    Anchorage EO-20 (enacted 17 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427202830/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/emergencyorder20-final-signed.pdf  Attachment C on entertainment venues:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427203849/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo-20%20attachment%20c%20-%20entertainment%2041221.pdf  Attachment D on organized sports:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414174904/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo-20%20attachment%20d%20-%20organized%20sports%2041221%20230pm.pdf
notes_C4: On April 17, Anchorage will lift all limits on outdoor gathering with mask and social distancing measure still in effect. Restrictions on indoor gathering (~35 people) will still be in place.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414200618/https://apnews.com/article/alaska-anchorage-coronavirus-pandemic-2d11a1668c1c3bd6f0dc6dd9bf39975f    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412225928/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/anchorage/2021/04/12/read-the-full-text-of-anchorages-emergency-order-lifting-outdoor-gathering-limitations/
notes_C5: The People Mover in Anchorage continues to operate with safety measures in place, " People Mover and AnchorRIDES continue to operate regular service and rider limits remain at 14-riders per 40-foot bus and 6-riders per vehicle on the neighborhood routes with 22-foot buses. Cloth face coverings are still required to ride People Mover."     https://archive.vn/II4oD
notes_C6: Anchorage's EO-19 encourages people to avoid contact with those outside their household and to limit trips outside the home.    Health Advisory No. 1 also remains in effect statewide ("Minimize time indoors with individuals outside your household even if you can maintain a distance of six feet. Avoid all gatherings, even small ones, with persons who are not in your household.")     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C7: Health Advisory No. 3 remains in effect (first issued Feb 14), which provides guidance on intrastate travel, including recommending testing, physical distancing, and quarantining as necessary both on and off the Road System and Alaska Marine Highway System. "Anyone who is currently infected with SARS-CoV-2 virus must not travel until they are cleared from isolation by a medical professional."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410204530/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-3-Intrastate-Travel.pdf
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Unemployment assistance is available. The Division of Public Assistance lists other resources available to Alaskans on their website.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211043/https://labor.alaska.gov/COVID-19-programs.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_E2: There are no active statewide moratoriums or suspensions of utility shutoffs. The CDC eviction moratorium is in effect. Those who qualified for the rental assistance program (applications closed March 5) will have access to 12 months of rental assistance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410213801/https://www.muni.org/Departments/Mayor/PressReleases/Pages/Municipality-of-Anchorage,-Cook-Inlet-Housing-Authority-partner-with-Alaska-Housing-to-distribute-up-to-12-months-of-rent-a.aspx
notes_H1: The public continues to be informed about Covid-19, vaccination and testing, etc. As an example:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410215810/https://public.govdelivery.com/assets/Signup.js
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is widely available to the public.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410220041/https://coronavirus-response-alaska-dhss.hub.arcgis.com/app/2d92b77bc8044329a1ee3954b063bd8c
notes_H3: Alaska has a contact tracing program, though it is not clear how thorough it is.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322232305/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_H6: Anchorage Assembly ends mask mandate effective immediately marking a significant policy change on mask mandate termination that was originally scheduled on May 21.  Currently (May 14 Update) over 37% and 42% of Alaskans are vaccinated fully and with at least one dose respectively.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515150017/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/anchorage/2021/05/14/anchorage-assembly-ends-mask-mandate-effective-immediately/
notes_H7: Appointments for Pfizer COVID-19 vaccination approved for over 40,000 eligible children ages 12-15 in Alaska.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515144114/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/2021/05/10/alaska-parents-can-now-schedule-covid-19-vaccine-appointments-for-children-12-and-up-officials-say/

name: Alabama
notes_C1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210510201540/https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2021/04/Safer-Apart-Order-Final-4.6.21.pdf
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210506120134/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509063451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: As of May 10th, the CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003542/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: no policy change.  Alabama remains under "Safer Apart Order" .    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144658/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/legal/assets/order-adph-cov-safer-apart-040721.pdf
notes_C5: no policy change.
notes_C6: no policy change.  Alabama remains under "Safer Apart Order" . Recommendations for staying at home are only applied to those who are feeling sick.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144658/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/legal/assets/order-adph-cov-safer-apart-040721.pdf
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: no policy change.
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: no policy change.
notes_H2: no policy change. If you have symptoms of COVID-19, you should get tested with a nasal test. If you have been exposed to COVID-19 but do not have symptoms you should wait at least 3-4 days after exposure before getting tested. The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) recommendation for testing is a PCR (nasal swab) test only.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210415211005/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19/patients.html
notes_H3: no policy change.
notes_H6: As of April 27th, the mask mandate for federal buildings and recommendations for mask-wearing on public transportation still stand.     The CDC updated its mask-wearing guidance on April 27th for those who have been fully vaccinated, stating:   "You can gather indoors with fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask or staying 6 feet apart."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427062253/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html  See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427035558/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/using-transportation.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426161816/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-the-federal-workforce-and-requiring-mask-wearing/
notes_H7: changing code from 4 to 5. " Beginning April 5, all individuals age 16 and older are eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in Alabama.  The Pfizer vaccine is the only COVID-19 vaccine currently approved for age 16 and older. Currently, our county health departments are giving the Moderna vaccine. Other providers, such as hospitals and some pharmacies, are giving the Pfizer vaccine. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419210551/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19vaccine/

name: Arkansas
notes_C1: There is a rise in cases in public schools, yet to sign of switching to online learning.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503194837/https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2021/apr/24/covid-cases-rise-at-public-schools/
notes_C2: guidance is still in place.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426185636/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-health-guidances
notes_C3: Arkansas Catholic Diocese loosens COVID-19 restrictions at churches across Arkansas. Starting this weekend, congregations may gather in Arkansas to attend mass without a face mask.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517195004/https://www.5newsonline.com/article/news/local/little-rock-diocese-loosens-covid-19-restrictions-at-catholic-churches-across-arkansas-no-mask-required/527-79106b1c-3b23-4528-9997-0e25bec2cb5a

However, events are strongly encouraged to continue to follow the  Guidelines to prevent the spread of COVID-19."so I am changing the value to 0.     link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322211431/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/guidance_largeindoorvenue.pdf
notes_C5: No change, some services in Little Rock are still not operating.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426185618/https://rrmetro.org/find-all-ongoing-transit-service-alerts-here/
notes_C6: People still are asked to stay at home if sick.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315190903/https://govstatus.egov.com/ar-covid-19

If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions. notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: Fresh Start is continuing to operate, and it is expanding. More Arkansans will be eligible for rental assistance payments under a new state-run program with higher income limits and simpler documentation requirements, officials said. A federal moratorium on evictions, enacted during the covid-19 pandemic, is scheduled to end June 30.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517195501/https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2021/may/17/new-program-eases-tenants-path-to-rental-aid/
notes_H1: link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201183718/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/novel-coronavirus
notes_H2: No change, testing is available if "If you have a fever, cough, or shortness of breath OR if you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 "     link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426183942/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-guidance-for-getting-tested
notes_H3: No change.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426184004/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-contact-tracing
notes_H6: On May 16th, the CDC update their guidelines stating:   "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic.  Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine authorized for 12-15 age group in Arkansas.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517200134/https://www.fayettevilleflyer.com/2021/05/12/pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-approved-for-12-15-age-group-in-arkansas/

name: Arizona
notes_C1: As of May 15, the previous note still stands: “All schools are required to offer in person options with differing mitigation requirements depending on spread level. The statewide school mask requirement has been dropped.”   Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420154500/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-04.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210513185633/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_C2: As of May 15, the previous note still stands: "On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation. Previous restrictions on businesses, such as gyms and indoor theatres, have been replaced by recommendations/suggestions.”  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210513063231/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf
notes_C3: As of May 15, the previous note still stands: “On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that events larger than 50 people no longer require local government approval. The city of Phoenix, however, requires applications for gatherings exceeding 50 people to be filed and approved before events can occur. All events require the use of masks and social distancing.”  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515152051/https://www.phoenix.gov/citymanager/specialevent
notes_C4: The previous note is still valid.
notes_C5: The previous note is still valid.
notes_C6: The previous note is still valid.

notes_E1: No policy change. Under the CAA, benefits are reduced and provided through unemployment assistance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210127043148/https://des.az.gov/services/employment/unemployment-individual
notes_E2: On May 7th "the U.S. Department of the Treasury, in coordination with the White House American Rescue Plan Implementation Team and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced the allocation of an additional $21.6 billion under the American Rescue Plan for Emergency Rental Assistance, which will help prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507202118/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0168
notes_H1: Coordinated public information campaign continues.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515150640/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_H2: Testing appears to remain generally available.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515150640/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_H3: As of May 15, the previous note still stands: "The State of Arizona is running a comprehensive contact tracing system that involves contacting people who tested positive for COVID-19 via phone call, monitoring symptoms with a text/email system, and contacting all of the people that the case has made close contact with while infectious.”  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515150640/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_H6: As of May 15, the city of Phoenix continues to exert its rights to maintain city-wide mask mandates in place, defying the governor’s executive order on March 25th which rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation. Additionally, on May 14th, Pima county revised it’s mask mandate to align with CDC recommendations in not requiring vaccinated individuals to wear masks in most public spaces.  Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405194611/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210515160722/https://www.phoenix.gov/newsroom/em-and-hs/1353  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515162423/https://webcms.pima.gov/cms/One.aspx?portalId=169&pageId=563362
notes_H7: As of May 14th, all Arizona counties have made the vaccine available to all people ages 12+. Pfizer, Moderna, and Janssen vaccines are being distributed across the state.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514003511/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/vaccines/index.php#general-vaccine-info

name: California
notes_C1: Individual University of California campuses have begun to release plans for fall instruction. Plans may be updated further in the future and campuses will be added as they release more information (see link). The UC system as a whole plans to return to primarily in-person instruction as of fall 2021. Spring classes, which conclude mid-June, have been primarily remote. At the K-12 level starting May 24 Los Angeles Unified will begin offering Covid-19 vaccines to middle and high school students during school hours in an effort to widen access to the vaccine, according to Superintendent Austin Beutner. Mobile sites at schools across the state aim to increase vaccination rates as approval for vaccine use in younger demographics is allowed.     *This coder tried to provide examples of school reopenings using the Safe Schools For All reopening map but on 5/18 it wasn't working properly.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518133658/https://edsource.org/news-updates    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518132933/https://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518133837/https://maps.schools.covid19.ca.gov/public.html
notes_C2: As of May 11th, 11 counties are in "substantial", 38 are in "moderate", and 9 are in "minimal" risk tiers (tiers 2, 3, 4) in California.   Substantial: Some non-essential indoor business operations are closed  Moderate: Some indoor business operations are open with modifications  Minimal: Most indoor business operations are open with modifications    Every county in California is assigned to a tier based on its positivity rate, adjusted case rate, and health equity metric.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518134208/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/
notes_C3: Public events are limited. Attendance at all gatherings are limited according to the County Risk Level. In the Substantial tier, festivals are closed. Concert venues can open with modifications for in-state attendees only, with advanced reservations.  Outdoors:  – Max capacity 20%  – Suite max capacity 25%  – In-seat concessions, no concourse sales    Indoors, all venues:  – No eating/drinking in seats, but in designated areas only  – Suites 25% capacity, max 3 households    Indoors, venues seating up to 1,500:  – Max 10% capacity or 100 people  – Max 25% capacity if all guests show proof of negative test or full vaccination    Indoors, venues seating 1,501 and above:  – Max 20% capacity if all guests show proof of negative test or full vaccination    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518134208/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511164134/https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-live-performances-indoor--en.pdf
notes_C4: As of May 11th, 11 counties are in "substantial", 38 are in "moderate", and 9 are in "minimal" risk tiers (tiers 2, 3, 4) in California. No counties are in the Widespread tier. The Substantial tier still limits indoor gatherings to 10 people/3 households or less.     Red – Substantial – Tier 2:  Outdoor gatherings: Maximum of 25 people  Indoor gatherings are strongly discouraged  Maximum 25% capacity where capacity limits exist and up to 3 households or 10 people.     Orange – Moderate – Tier 3:  Outdoor gatherings: Maximum of 50 people, Indoor gatherings are strongly discouraged  Maximum 25% capacity where capacity limits exist or 25 people, whichever is fewer.     Yellow – Minimal – Tier4 :  Outdoor gatherings: Maximum of 100 people  Indoor gatherings are strongly discouraged  Maximum 50% capacity where capacity limits exist or 50 people, whichever is fewer.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511165332/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Guidance-for-the-Prevention-of-COVID-19-Transmission-for-Gatherings-November-2020.aspx
notes_C5: The BART (Bay Area Rapid Transit) has reduced service and implemented early closures during the pandemic, according to a March 22 news update the reductions will continue to be in place, with the system closing at 9 PM. Since this is not a full closure, keeping the code a 0.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518135422/https://www.bart.gov/news/articles/2020/news20200406
notes_C6: The state's "California For All" Covid-19 website continues to urge everyone to "Stay home except for essential needs."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518134208/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/
notes_C7: California's travel advisory suggests that Californians should avoid non-essential travel outside of California, to other states or countries unless they are fully vaccinated.   Non-essential travelers from other states or countries are strongly discouraged from entering California and should adhere to the quarantine procedures. Non-essential travelers who are not fully vaccinated should get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before travel, and get tested 3-5 days upon arrival to their destination. They should stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel, even if their test is negative.  Non-essential travelers who are not fully vaccinated and don't get tested should stay home and self-quarantine for 10 days after travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518140009/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Travel-Advisory.aspx
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: California's Labor & Workforce Development Agency provides a helpful chart outlining the various forms of financial support available to Californians during the pandemic, including California supplemental Covid-19 paid sick leave. See link.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518141339/https://www.labor.ca.gov/coronavirus2019/
notes_E2: No recent changes. The California Public Utilities Commission extended utility customer protection measures directing energy, water, and communications companies under CPUC jurisdiction to suspend customer disconnections for non-payments from April 16, 2021 to June 30, 2021.    The EO extending the statewide moratorium on evictions continues to be in place, lasting through June 30, 2021. Eviction protection is available to anyone with a coronavirus-related hardship, like loss of or reduction income.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511185836/https://covid19.ca.gov/get-financial-help/    PUC: https://web.archive.org/web/20210511190251/https://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/PublishedDocs/Published/G000/M365/K316/365316626.PDF    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511190354/https://www.gov.ca.gov/2021/01/29/governor-newsom-signs-legislation-to-extend-eviction-moratorium-and-assist-tenants-and-small-property-owners-impacted-by-covid-19/
notes_H1: Public information continues to be regularly updated and disseminated by the state.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518142115/https://covid19.ca.gov/
notes_H2: On May 17, 177,223 tests were used in California, with a 0.9% test positivity rate. Testing is widely available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518142504/https://covid19.ca.gov/state-dashboard/
notes_H3: California's contact tracing efforts is decentralized at the county level and data is not readily accessible to determine how widespread contact tracing is statewide. According to data from Santa Clara County's Public Health Department's Case Investigation and Contact Tracing Dashboard, 85% of cases have been interviewed and 86% of contacts have been interviewed in the past 90 days. Santa Clara County is the 6th most populous county in the state. In comparison, Los Angeles County, the most populous in the state, had a 46.3% rate of cases that completed an interview in the past 7 days (44.9% cumulatively), with 76% of contacts completing an interview in a 7 day period (64.5% cumulatively).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518221949/https://covid19.sccgov.org/dashboard-contact-tracing    https://archive.vn/DlONG
notes_H6: California will keep existing mask guidance in place until June 15 when it aims to fully reopen the economy. After that, the state plans to allow fully-vaccinated Californians to go without a mask in most indoor settings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518224120/https://covid19.ca.gov/masks-and-ppe/
notes_H7: COVID-19 vaccines are now available to everyone age 12 and up for free (government funded). Johnson and Johnson, Moderna, and Pfizer are all in use, with Pfizer the only vaccine approved for use in 12-17 year olds. Statewide, nearly 50% of people are fully vaccinated.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518225545/https://covid19.ca.gov/vaccination-progress-data/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518225220/https://myturn.ca.gov/

name: Colorado
notes_C1: April 28, Colorado State University and University of Colorado will require upcoming its students to be vaccinated before attending fall semester, joining three other higher education institutions (Fort Lewis College, University of Denver, and Colorado Spring College) These measures are in full support of Gov. Polis.    Source:  https://www.9news.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/colorado-colleges-covid-vaccine-requirements/73-319233b5-e776-41a3-8352-480ef5eb629b
notes_C2: On April 16, Colorado dropped its COVID-19 dial and statewide mandates, shifting responsibility to county and local leaders. https://archive.fo/ucv6Z    New capacity limits for Denver will include the following: (https://archive.ph/Zj7a4)    75% capacity at offices  75% capacity for retail businesses  100% capacity for gyms, recreation centers and pools, with six-foot distancing between non-household members  100% capacity for restaurants, with 6-foot distancing between parties and a group size limit of 10  25% capacity for bars that do not serve food, not to exceed 75 people  Alcohol beverage sales at bars/restaurants allowed until 2 a.m.  Indoor seated events at up to 100% capacity for up to 500 people in a room (excluding staff) with six-foot distancing between groups of up to 10   Outdoor seated and unseated events with fewer than 5,000 attendees at 100% capacity
notes_C3: On April 16, Colorado dropped its COVID-19 dial and statewide mandates, shifting responsibility to county and local leaders. https://archive.fo/ucv6Z    New capacity limits for Denver will include the following: (https://archive.ph/Zj7a4)    75% capacity at offices  75% capacity for retail businesses  100% capacity for gyms, recreation centers and pools, with six-foot distancing between non-household members  100% capacity for restaurants, with 6-foot distancing between parties and a group size limit of 10  25% capacity for bars that do not serve food, not to exceed 75 people  Alcohol beverage sales at bars/restaurants allowed until 2 a.m.  Indoor seated events at up to 100% capacity for up to 500 people in a room (excluding staff) with six-foot distancing between groups of up to 10   Outdoor seated and unseated events with fewer than 5,000 attendees at 100% capacity
notes_C4: On April 16, Colorado dropped its COVID-19 dial and statewide mandates, shifting responsibility to county and local leaders. https://archive.fo/ucv6Z    New capacity limits for Denver will include the following: (https://archive.ph/Zj7a4)    75% capacity at offices  75% capacity for retail businesses  100% capacity for gyms, recreation centers and pools, with six-foot distancing between non-household members  100% capacity for restaurants, with 6-foot distancing between parties and a group size limit of 10  25% capacity for bars that do not serve food, not to exceed 75 people  Alcohol beverage sales at bars/restaurants allowed until 2 a.m.  Indoor seated events at up to 100% capacity for up to 500 people in a room (excluding staff) with six-foot distancing between groups of up to 10   Outdoor seated and unseated events with fewer than 5,000 attendees at 100% capacity
notes_C5: RTD's COVID-19 service plan continues - mask-wearing requirements, limited capacity on buses, services/lines running reduced.     https://archive.fo/d7n4B
notes_C6: On April 16, Colorado dropped its COVID-19 dial and statewide mandates, shifting responsibility to county and local leaders. https://archive.fo/ucv6Z
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Governor Polis extended an Executive Order ordering expedited unemployment insurance claim processing to provide relief to Coloradans impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Governor Polis also extended an Executive Order that allows Colorado taxpayers to file their state income tax returns by the extended deadline of May 17, 2021, to align with the deadline extension for federal tax returns.    https://archive.fo/JSyil
notes_E2: Governor Polis signed an Executive Order related to the protection of tenants from eviction during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in Colorado.  Under the Executive Order, tenants now have a 30-day period to cure any default for nonpayment of rent. Previously, tenants only had a ten-day cure period.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422203641/https://www.colorado.gov/governor/news/4886-governor-polis-takes-action-response-covid-19-pandemic
notes_H1: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) launched the "Power the Comeback" information campaign to bolster access to credible COVID-19 vaccine information.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210416140354/https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/state-asks-coloradans-to-power-the-comeback
notes_H2: CDPHE expands at-home COVID-19 testing program (Binax At-home Rapid Testing Kit) to all public-facing employees free of charge. Public-facing employees include, but is not limited to retail workers, hotel and other hospitality employees, delivery and truck drivers, etc.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210413161727/https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/cdphe-expands-at-home-covid-19-testing-program-to-all-public-facing-employees
notes_H3: Couldn't find more recent news, but sources in mid-late November indicate that contact tracing capacity wasn't keeping up with the number of surging cases at the time.  Links: https://archive.fo/00vsj ; https://archive.fo/wH1g5    More recent (Jan 10) anecdote/Twitter thread suggesting limited contact tracing: https://archive.fo/dkEVT
notes_H6: Second amended public health order 20-38 no longer requires fully vaccinated individuals to wear masks in most settings.     https://archive.fo/F4af7
notes_H7: "As part of Governor Polis’ Vaccines for All efforts, the State of Colorado is allocating vaccines to community-based organizations. All of these clinics focus on vaccinating underserved Coloradans and span a variety of diverse communities."    https://archive.fo/aAjbu

notes_C1: No change:   "The state is moving ahead full throttle to get all students back inside classrooms come the fall, but the efforts will most likely fall short, Gov. notes_C3: No change    April 2 updates:   - indoor stadiums can open at 10% capacity  - fairs and festivals at 50% of last year's capacity - face masks and social distancing required  - outdoor events capped at 50% capacity with max 10,000 people  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422214457/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Gatherings
notes_C4: No change:     April 2 updates:   - indoor stadiums can open at 10% capacity  - fairs and festivals at 50% of last year's capacity - face masks and social distancing required  - outdoor events capped at 50% capacity with max 10,000 people      Indoor private residences still capped at 25 people    https://web.archive.org/web/20210422214457/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Gatherings
notes_C5: No change
notes_C6: Update: "As of April 2, 2021, CDC has updated their travel guidance; since fully vaccinated travelers are less likely to contract and spread COVID-19, they can travel safely within the United States.    Fully vaccinated persons, meaning persons who are at least 14 days or more after the last dose of their vaccine series, can travel within the United States and do not have to test before or after travel (unless their destination requires it) and do not have to quarantine after travel.    Fully vaccinated persons should still:    Wear a mask over their nose and mouth  Stay 6 feet from others and avoid crowds  Wash hands often or use hand sanitizer"    For unvaccinated:   Before Travel:   Plan ahead and check if your airline or destination requires testing, health information, or other documentation.  Some destinations require a viral test 1-3 days prior to travel. Visit the Connecticut Testing Locator or call 211 to locate a testing site.  Keep a copy of your test results with you during travel in case you are asked for them.  Anyone who develops signs/symptoms of COVID-19 prior to travel should stay home and get tested.    After Travel:  Review CDC guidance for post-travel quarantine and testing  Get tested 3-5 days after travel AND self-quarantine at home for a full 7 days after travel.  Continue to stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel, even if your test is negative.  If your test is positive, isolate yourself to protect others from getting infected.  If you do not get tested, stay home and self-quarantine for a full 10 days after travel.  Remember to self-monitor for signs and symptoms of COVID-19 while in quarantine. If at any time during your quarantine you develop signs and symptoms of COVID-19, self-isolate (including away from other members of your travel party), contact a healthcare provider, and seek testing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422211730/https://portal.ct.gov/coronavirus/travel

notes_C8: As of April 27th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426160314/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426010332/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: Public health emergency extended until at least May 20  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422213207/https://ctmirror.org/2021/04/19/eviction-moratorium-extended-until-public-health-emergency-order-ends/    From the executive order 9P:  "NOW, THEREFORE, I, NED LAMONT, Governor of the State of Connecticut, by virtue of the  authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the State of Connecticut, and pursuant  to the public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on March 10, 2020 and renewed on September 1, 2020 and the new public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on September 1, 2020, do hereby ORDER AND DIRECT:    1. Increase in Weekly Benefit Amount and Qualification for Lost Wages Assistance. Notwithstanding any provision of Chapter 567 of the Connecticut General Statutes to the contrary, during the weeks beginning July 26, 2020, and ending on September 5, 2020, individuals who were eligible for a Weekly Benefit Amount of less than $100.00 and had not exhausted their state regular unemployment benefits by July 26, 2020, shall have their Weekly Benefit Amount raised to $100.00, and such individuals shall be permitted to apply for Lost Wages Assistance as a result. With respect to employers who make payments in lieu of contributions pursuant to Section 31-225 of the Connecticut General Statutes (reimbursing employers), for individuals who are affected by this Executive Order No. 9P, the amount otherwise due from the employer in lieu of contributions shall be reduced by an amount equal to the difference between the individual’s Weekly Benefit Amount to be paid pursuant to this Order and the Weekly Benefit Amount which was or would have been calculated pursuant to Chapter 567 prior to this Order. The Commissioner of Labor may issue any implementing orders that he deems necessary to effectuate this order.    This order shall take effect immediately and remain in effect for the duration of the existing  renewed and newly declared civil preparedness and public health emergencies, unless earlier  modified or terminated by me."    From executive order 10:  "Exclusion of individual stimulus payments from benefit eligibility calculations: Repeats and expands the provisions of Executive Order No. 7CC, which exempted any CARES Act stimulus payments from eligibility calculations for state-provided benefits. This expands the exemption to all federal COVID-related stimulus to capture CARES Act II stimulus."    Sources:  https://archive.vn/gkjem    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192050/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9P.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192106/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-10.pdf
notes_E2: "Gov. Ned Lamont plans to extend the state’s eviction moratorium until the public health emergency expires on May 20."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422213207/https://ctmirror.org/2021/04/19/eviction-moratorium-extended-until-public-health-emergency-order-ends/    "Governor Ned Lamont, members of Connecticut’s Congressional delegation, and Connecticut Housing Commissioner Seila Mosquera-Bruno today announced the launch of UniteCT, a new state program to provide rental and utility assistance to qualified Connecticut households financially impacted by COVID-19.    As further detailed in the program guidelines, UniteCT may provide up to $10,000 in rental assistance and up to $1,500 in electric utility arrearage payments to landlords and utility companies on behalf of approved tenants. Tenants and landlords will be able to complete and track applications online from any computer or smart phone. Assistance will be available through a call center and at housing counseling agencies and other community partners across the state."    Source:  https://archive.vn/WbftJ
notes_H1: Notes  No change. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319095243/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base
notes_H2: No change.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322041525/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/COVID-19-Testing
notes_H3: No change.    "Contact tracing is the process of contacting all people who have tested positive for COVID-19 or have had contact with someone who tested positive. It is possible to be infected with COVID-19 and have no symptoms, so contact tracing is currently one of the best ways to identify and notify people who may be infected in order to slow the spread of COVID-19. Participating in contact tracing is a way to protect you, your family, and your community.    Contact tracers from the local and state health department will be in touch with you if you test positive for COVID-19, and will also call people you were in close contact with – but will keep your information protected. You will see “CT COVID TRACE” or the number for your local health department on your caller ID."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322043051/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/ContaCT
notes_H6: "Gov. Ned Lamont announced on April 27 that the state will be following new Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines on the wearing of masks outdoors, which says that fully vaccinated individuals do not need to wear face coverings unless they are in a crowd of strangers... The change in the guidelines began immediately."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210428211128/https://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/coronavirus/do-i-need-to-wear-a-mask-outdoors-in-connecticut/2476235/
notes_H7: Recoded from 4 to 5, with evidence of actualized rollouts (vaccines in arms)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503091942/https://ctmirror.org/2021/04/05/nearly-three-quarters-of-eligible-ct-residents-expected-to-be-vaccinated-by-end-of-april/    "Students, employees, and residents 16 and older now eligible for vaccine     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404194108/https://portal.ct.gov/vaccine-portal/COVID-19-Vaccination-Phases    "Those who are 16 and 17 years old can only register for the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The vaccines developed by Moderna and Johnson & Johnson have only been approved for use on those 18 and older."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404194822/https://www.ctpost.com/news/coronavirus/article/Live-Connecticut-opens-vaccines-to-anyone-16-and-16068352.php "

name: Washington DC
notes_C1: School closing policy remains the same.
notes_C2: Workplace policy remains the same.
notes_C3: Public events still remain the same.
notes_C4: On May 9th, D.C. restaurants will be allowed to seat up to 10 people in a single party, and customers who want to drink outside will no longer have to buy a food item to go with their beverages, but indoor dining capacity will remain at a 25-percent cap that has been in place since late January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426175422/https://dc.eater.com/2021/4/26/22403887/dc-restaurant-capacity-party-size-10-people-covid-19-update
notes_C5: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C6: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C7: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: Extensive protections remain. This policy remains coded at 2.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316220040/https://coronavirus.dc.gov/utilityhelp
notes_H1: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H2: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H3: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H6: On May 15, "Virginia lifted its statewide indoor mask mandate, but there are places where face coverings are still required. Residents who are fully vaccinated will no longer need to wear masks indoors except on public transit, in health care and "in congregate settings.'    -Anyone not vaccinated is strongly encouraged to wear masks in all settings, as recommended by the CDC.  -Employees in regulated business, retail, restaurants, fitness, personal care and entertainment are required to continue to wear masks until fully vaccinated.  -Businesses may require masks, if they wish, for employees and patrons.  -Masks continue to be required in K-12 school settings, regardless of vaccination status.  -Maryland Mask and Face Covering Rules  -Maryland has ended its statewide mask mandate, but businesses and localities can keep their own policies.    Face coverings will still be required on public transportation, and in schools, child care and health care settings    The Maryland Department of Health issued a public health advisory strongly recommending that all non-vaccinated individuals over the age of 2 continue to wear face coverings in all indoor settings and in outdoor settings where physical distancing cannot be maintained."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515140123/https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/coronavirus/are-masks-required-in-dc-maryland-and-virginia-here-are-local-regulations/2673165/
notes_H7: As of April 12, 2021, all Washington DC residents age 16 and older are eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. Vaccines offered include Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson&Johnson. This policy has thus been upgraded from 3G to 5G, as eligibility is now universal for 16+.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412205310/https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/release_content/attachments/Situational-Update-Presentation_04-12-21.pdf

name: Delaware
notes_C1: As of May 16, a number of schools in Delaware are operating in-person learning, remote learning or a hybrid learning model. For example, the Christina School District is offering a hybrid learning model but will be offering vaccines for children aged 12+ from May 17 to expand their in-person learning.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210516192607/https://www.christinak12.org/Page/4703
notes_C2: As of May 16, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. There will be modifications to this that will come into effect on May 21 that will eliminate most business capacity caps. However currently, the order is allowing some sectors to reopen under the phase 2 reopening plan (food and drinks establishments, retail premises and museums, for example) with restrictions regarding social distancing, hygiene and reduced capacity limits. Some sectors such as indoor children's play areas, arcades and water parks are not allowed to reopen unless they submit facility-specific plans to the state for consideration. For this reason, it is still be coded at 2T until the modifications come into effect on May 21.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C3: As of May 16, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney is still in effect. Modifications to this order will come into effect on May 21. Regarding public events, while some outdoor gatherings can take place this order states "notwithstanding the occupancy determinations in this paragraph, any fire occupancy requirements that would permit more than one hundred and fifty (150) people at any one time must first submit a plan to DPH. Plans may not be implemented until approved by DPH." While some public events with smaller groups can go ahead, they must follow strict guidelines and anything larger has to be approved by the DPH. Any gathering over 250 people after May 21 will still require DPH approval.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516193059/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/05/12/governor-carney-updates-covid-19-order-eliminates-capacity-restrictions-effective-may-21/
notes_C4: As of May 16, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. Modifications to this order will come into effect on May 21. Currently regarding indoor gatherings, this order states "Indoor gatherings or events at any business or indoor space open to the public of up to the lesser of fifty percent (50%) stated fire occupancy or twenty-five (25) people (e.g. weddings and receptions, graduations, birthday parties, funeral receptions, etc.) and private indoor gatherings or events of up to ten (10) persons (e.g. dinner parties, house parties, birthday parties) are permitted in Phase 2" if a number of social distancing and hygiene requirements are met. Regarding outdoor events this order states "Any business or space without a stated fire occupancy requirement may host outdoor social, community, recreational, and leisure events of no more than one hundred and fifty (150) people, including but not limited to weddings, funerals, concerts, parades, festivals, conventions, fundraisers, sporting events and fairs". This is coded as 4G to reflect the limitations on indoor gatherings. On May 21, many businesses will have capacity limits removed, but events with over 250 people will still require DPH approval.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211328/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Seventh-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02192021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516193059/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/05/12/governor-carney-updates-covid-19-order-eliminates-capacity-restrictions-effective-may-21/
notes_C5: As of 19th April 2021, there is no evidence of public transport closures in Delaware. The DART's strategy outline indicates that most services are running as normal.     Source: https://archive.vn/iWuEb
notes_C6: The official advice of the Delaware government is to "stay home if you are sick", but as of 19th April 2021 there are no further stay at home requirements, so this indicator remains at 0.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419125921/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/
notes_C7: As of May 16, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. This order will undergo modifications that will come into effect on May 21. At present, this order maintains that individuals who travel out of state for sporting competitions are "strongly encouraged to immediately self-quarantine in accordance with DPH guidance from the time of entry into Delaware or for the duration of the individual’s presence in Delaware, whichever period is shorter".     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211328/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Seventh-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02192021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516193059/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/05/12/governor-carney-updates-covid-19-order-eliminates-capacity-restrictions-effective-may-21/
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The additional temporary food benefits given to Delaware households affected by the lack of free school meals last up to July 2021. As these benefits are temporary and specifically related to the pandemic, and as they amount to only $6.82 per eligible child per day, this indicator remains at 1F.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329212729/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/03/29/delaware-households-affected-by-school-closings-during-pandemic-will-receive-additional-temporary-food-benefits/
notes_E2: As of 19th April 2021, Delaware's Covid-19 Rental Assistance programme is still in effect. Therefore this indicator remains at 2.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412152329/https://decovidhousinghelp.com/
notes_H1: As of May 16, Delaware is operating a coordinated public health campaign.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426210712/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/community-resources/
notes_H2: As of May 16, the state of Delaware is offering testing to anyone who wants one. Testing methods available include at home testing, community sites or antigen testing/rapid tests.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426211041/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/testing/
notes_H3: As of May 16, the Delaware Contact Tracing Program is still operating a comprehensive contact tracing system.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426211204/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: As of May 16, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney is in effect. This order was last modified on 1 April 2021. On May 21, modifications to this order will come into effect but mask wearing will still be required indoors. At present, this order states that face coverings must be worn in public. There are very few circumstances where face coverings are not mandatory as the order states they are "not required in an outdoor space open to the public when an individual can maintain at least six (6) feet of social distance between members of separate households, unless otherwise specified" or in certain circumstances like eating or drinking.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211328/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Seventh-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02192021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516193059/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/05/12/governor-carney-updates-covid-19-order-eliminates-capacity-restrictions-effective-may-21/
notes_H7: As of May 16, vaccines are universally available (Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson and Johnson). The Pfizer vaccine is now available to children aged 12+.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210516194549/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/vaccine/

name: Florida
notes_C1: No new updates. Effective May 3, 2021, Governor DeSantis issued Executive Order 21-102 which suspends all remaining local government mandates and restrictions based on the Covid-19 state of emergency. "This order eliminates and supersedes any existing emergency order or  ordinance issued by a county or municipality that imposes restrictions or mandates upon businesses or individuals due to the COVID-19 emergency."    (Code remains 0, as while some schools, such as those in Miami-Dade and Broward counties, will still require masks throughout the end of the school year, this does not seem to fit the "alterations resulting in significant differences" description to be coded as a 1 (?). In addition, Florida schools are at 100% in-person capacity according to the Return to Learn tracker.)     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517013829/https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/education/article251148824.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210512182950/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-102.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517013933/https://www.returntolearntracker.net/
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210506120134/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509063451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: As of May 10th, the CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003542/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: No new updates. Effective May 3, 2021, Governor DeSantis issued Executive Order 21-102 which suspends all remaining local government mandates and restrictions based on the Covid-19 state of emergency. "This order eliminates and supersedes any existing emergency order or  ordinance issued by a county or municipality that imposes restrictions or mandates upon businesses or individuals due to the COVID-19 emergency."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210512182950/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-102.pdf
notes_C5: No new updates. Effective May 3, 2021, Governor DeSantis issued Executive Order 21-102 which suspends all remaining local government mandates and restrictions based on the Covid-19 state of emergency. "This order eliminates and supersedes any existing emergency order or  ordinance issued by a county or municipality that imposes restrictions or mandates upon businesses or individuals due to the COVID-19 emergency."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210512182950/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-102.pdf
notes_C6: No new updates. Effective May 3, 2021, Governor DeSantis issued Executive Order 21-102 which suspends all remaining local government mandates and restrictions based on the Covid-19 state of emergency. "This order eliminates and supersedes any existing emergency order or  ordinance issued by a county or municipality that imposes restrictions or mandates upon businesses or individuals due to the COVID-19 emergency."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210512182950/https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-102.pdf
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: On May 7th "the U.S. Department of the Treasury, in coordination with the White House American Rescue Plan Implementation Team and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced the allocation of an additional $21.6 billion under the American Rescue Plan for Emergency Rental Assistance, which will help prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507202118/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0168
notes_H1: No new updates. The Florida Dept. of Health continues to provide information regarding Covid-19 on its website.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517015256/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/
notes_H2: No new updates. Testing continues to vary by site with many sites offering tests to those asymptomatic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210501144219/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/testing-sites/
notes_H3: No new updates. No evidence to suggest contact tracing in Florida is "comprehensive."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517015854/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/frequently-asked-questions/
notes_H6: On May 16th, the CDC update their guidelines stating:   "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic.  Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: The Pfizer vaccine is now approved for those 12 and older.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020343/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/vaccines/
