name: Hawaii
notes_C1: According to the Hawaii Department of Education press release on March 11, "The Hawaii State Department of Education (HIDOE) recently announced a goal to increase in-person instruction at elementary schools during the fourth quarter (March 22-May 28). The overall aim is to safely maximize in-person learning opportunities for elementary students for the remainder of the 2020-21 school year. Because campuses are in various stages of reopening, timing will vary by school."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504190333/https://www.hawaiipublicschools.org/ConnectWithUs/MediaRoom/PressReleases/Pages/Fourth-Quarter-Reopening-Ramp-Up.aspx
notes_C2: The March 24, 2021 Emergency Order 2021-04, issued by the Mayor of the city and county of Honolulu is still in effect. The City and County of Honolulu are currently in Tier 3 (out of 4) during a "pause and evaluation" period until at least May 5. Essential business is allowed, but "All businesses with a facility in the City, except Essential Businesses, and Designated Businesses and Operations, are required to cease all activities within such facilities, except Minimum Basic Operations. For clarity, businesses may also continue operations consisting exclusively of employees or contractors performing activities at their own residences (i.e., working from home)." The Order is in effect through May 10, 2021.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210428230834/http://www.honolulu.gov/rep/site/may/may_docs/2103140-CCH_Emergency_Order_No._2021-04_certified_-_signed.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504191007/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening-strategy
notes_C3: Social gatherings continue to be limited (as of May 4). In the "Act with Care" level, residents are advised to adhere to guidelines to limit crowds. Dance, social, and night life establishments remain closed in the city and county of Honolulu in Tier 3.  Social gatherings are capped at 10 people. "Static events" are allowed at reduced capacity with assigned seats, weddings capped at 100 people and must be outside. On Maui, exceptions to provisions for special events must be approved by the County of Maui. "Under the supervision of professional event planners or venues, commercial events (such as luau) may be conducted with the following restrictions: a. Outdoor venues only. b. Maximum 100 persons, including staff. c. Table seating required. Maximum of 10 persons per table. Each table should be reserved for members of the same household only (no intermixing of parties).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210505004610/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening-strategy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505004756/https://www.mauicounty.gov/DocumentCenter/View/125111/COM_Public-Health-Emergency-Rules
notes_C4: "Gov. David Ige approved Kaua‘i Mayor Derek Kawakami’s updated Business & Recreation Guidelines tier chart, and the county’s move to Tier 3 on Thursday.    The more cautious tier was activated after the island’s average case count remained elevated for the past two weeks. This is the first time Kaua‘i has moved tiers since the guidelines were approved in October 2020.    Ahead of the tier change, the county proposed modifications to the chart to better reflect its current situation and the latest health guidelines. The updated Tier 3 guidelines reduce the indoor social gathering limit to five while allowing groups of 25 outdoors. They allow team sports to continue with COVID-safe protocols in place. Each county has its own tier guidelines and this announcement applies only to Kaua‘i."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510210436/https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/office-of-the-governor-news-release-governor-ige-approves-kauais-move-to-tier-3-with-updated-guidelines/
notes_C5: Based on searches, there are no measures to close public transportation. Honolulu's bus service encourages riders to limit their bus/van trips to essential travel only.    https://archive.vn/5cVSu
notes_C6: The City and County of Honolulu's Emergency Order 2021-04, which went into effect March 24 and will remain in effect through May 10, 2021.   "All individuals currently living within the City may leave their residences to engage in Essential Activities, maintain Essential Governmental Functions, operate/visit Essential Businesses, or operate/visit/utilize Designated Businesses and Operations. All other activities, businesses, and operations are prohibited."    The County of Maui's emergency rules continue to be in effect, with Rule 1: Act with Care stating, "All individuals currently within the County are  encouraged to stay at their residence or place of lodging, except as provided in these Rules" (for essential activities, etc).     Maui: https://archive.vn/s7cg0  Honolulu: https://archive.vn/QcejT
notes_C7: "Gov. David Ige today signed the 20th proclamation on COVID-19, to allow inter-county travelers vaccinated in the State of Hawai‘i to bypass the pre-travel testing and/or quarantine requirement starting May 11. The state’s Safe Travels platform went online today, allowing travelers to upload their travel information and vaccination data.    The 20th proclamation addresses only the inter-county travel vaccine exception which continues for the duration of the previous 19th proclamation. The 19th proclamation —  which includes the eviction moratorium prohibiting evictions for failure to pay rent, and the extension of expirations for driver’s licenses, state IDs and permits – continues through June 8, 2021. The provisions will be re-evaluated to determine if they will be included in the next proclamation."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510210300/https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/office-of-the-governor-news-release-governor-ige-signs-20th-proclamation-on-covid-19-authorizing-quarantine-exception-for-inter-county-travelers-vaccinated-in-hawaii/
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Income support continues to be in place, including pandemic unemployment benefits. Hawaii's Department of Labor provides additional resources on their website for those who have exhausted their benefits.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505175055/https://labor.hawaii.gov/blog/main/resources-for-unemployment-insurance-claimants-with-exhausted-benefits/
notes_E2: Gov. David Ige’s 19th emergency proclamation for COVID-19 extends the eviction moratorium, prohibiting evictions of tenants for failure to pay all or a portion of the rent, maintenance fees, utility charges, taxes or other required fees for the rental unit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426210158/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2104031-ATG_Nineteenth-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf
notes_H1: The state's website on Covid-19 resources remains active and updated regularly.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505173548/https://hawaiicovid19.com/
notes_H2: Testing is widely available, including some free testing options, across the state.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505171635/https://hawaiicovid19.com/testing-isolation-quarantine/
notes_H3: Up-to-date information on contact tracing in Hawaii remains elusive.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505174047/https://hiema-hub.hawaii.gov/app/2c689a448b3045ccafdf86c40a8bf37e
notes_H6: Governor Ige's Proclamation 19, which extends until June, continues the statewide face covering requirement. All people ages 5 and older are required to wear masks over nose and mouth when in public, with some exceptions.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426210158/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2104031-ATG_Nineteenth-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505170116/https://hawaiicovid19.com/mask-guidance/
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    "In partnership with health care providers and state health officials, the Hawai‘i State Department of Education (HIDOE) is launching a statewide effort to vaccinate thousands of eligible public school students now that vaccines are available to residents 16 years and older.    The initiative kicked off at Waipahu High School today with a mobile COVID-19 vaccination clinic on wheels sponsored by Hawai‘i Pacific Health. Based on current enrollment and student ages, the population of students ages 16 and older in Hawai‘i public schools is approximately 32,000."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510210436/https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/office-of-the-governor-news-release-governor-ige-approves-kauais-move-to-tier-3-with-updated-guidelines/

notes_C4: As of May 15th, there had been no new Covid-19 policy since April 30th. https://web.archive.org/web/20210515042610if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/proclamations
notes_C5: As of May 15th, there had been no new Covid-19 policy since April 30th. https://web.archive.org/web/20210515042610if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/proclamations

notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of April 6th, individuals who were unemployed were still eligible to receive payment between $203 and $605 per week. Because the benefits were under 50% of the median salary in Iowa in 2020 ($43,000), this policy is coded 1F.    PUA: http://web.archive.org/web/20210320204336/https://www.iowaworkforcedevelopment.gov/pua-information   Median salary: http://web.archive.org/web/20210312055736/https://dqydj.com/average-income-by-state-median-top-percentiles/
notes_E2: As of April 13th, the federal moratorium on evictions was still in place. The moratorium is set to expire on June 30th.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419062920/https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/29/success/cdc-eviction-order-extended/index.html
notes_H1: As of May 8th, the state of Iowa along with the Iowa Department of Health were still active in coordinating Covid-19 public campaign.    Twitter: https://web.archive.org/web/20210508092459/https://twitter.com/IAPublicHealth/status/1389702956342288386   Iowa's Covid-19 website: https://web.archive.org/web/20210508092616if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/
notes_H2: As of May 8th, there were 5 active test sites and 13 active test clinics across Iowa. While anybody could make an appointment in order to get tested, only individuals with Covid-19 symptoms would be prioritized.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210508092616if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420064601if_/https://www.testiowa.com/en
notes_H3: s of May 8th, there was no indication that the state of Iowa had intensified its contract tracing efforts. Thus, the code remains the same.
notes_H6: On May 14th, Cedar Rapids, Des Moines, Dubuque, and Waterloo dropped their mask mandate following the newest CDC guidelines. Meanwhile, Iowa City's mandate was still in place as city officials reviewing the CDC guidelines. Iowa City planned to update its policy on Wednesday, May 19th.     Cedar Rapids and Des Moines: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515043327/https://www.radioiowa.com/2021/05/14/mayors-lift-mask-mandates-in-des-moines-cedar-rapids/   Dubuque: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515043740/https://www.telegraphherald.com/news/breaking/article_bb7feffb-b240-5955-a2ca-d8f2f1310671.html   Waterloo: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515044046/https://kwwl.com/2021/05/14/waterloo-mayor-updates-mask-mandate-to-follow-cdc-guidelines/   Iowa City: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515044456/https://www.kcrg.com/2021/05/15/iowa-city-to-review-and-update-covid-19-measures/
notes_H7: Despite the acknowledgement of vaccine shortage on Iowa government’s website, there was plenty of vaccine in Iowa this week due to weakening demand. 43 out of 99 counties in Iowa declined vaccine shipment. The shipment was rerouted to other counties in Iowa that needed it. Therefore, the code is changed to 5 - Universal.    News: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424050931/https://www.thegazette.com/health-care-medicine/as-vaccine-demand-slows-in-iowa-public-health-pivots-to-outreach/   News: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424051354/https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/latest-india-reports-record-number-cases-deaths-77208207  Iowa government’s website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424051455/https://vaccinate.iowa.gov/eligibility/

name: Idaho
notes_C1: K-12 schools remain open in Idaho, with all but 8 districts reporting in-person learning. The other 8 were hybrid (mix of in-person and online).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503030432/https://ioem.maps.arcgis.com/sharing/oauth2/authorize?client_id=opsdashboard&response_type=token&state=%7B%22portalUrl%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fioem.maps.arcgis.com%22%7D&expiration=20160&redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fioem.maps.arcgis.com%2Fapps%2Fopsdashboard%2Findex.html&redirectToUserOrgUrl=true
notes_C2: On May 2, Idaho is still operating under its "Stage 3 Stay Healthy Guidelines", which allow businesses to open as long as hygiene and distancing is being kept, and the following bar/restaurant guidelines are in place:  "All patrons should remain seated while consuming food or drink or when otherwise remaining on the premises, except for when entering, exiting, or using the restroom; seating should be arranged and maintained so that tables are spaced at least six feet apart; and nightclubs should continue to operate as a bar, subject to the requirements of this Section".     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025711/https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-3-stay-healthy-guidelines/
notes_C3: As of May 2, Idaho is still operating under its "Stage 3 Stay Healthy Guidelines" which state "Gatherings should be limited to 50 or fewer people and adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 3 [of the guidelines]"  Gatherings of over 50 may occur under the following:  "Gatherings exceeding the size and capacity limitations specified in Section 1(a) may receive an exemption if the organizer submits a plan for the gathering to the local health district having authority where the gathering is to occur and signs an attestation agreeing to comply with the provisions of the plan submitted to the local health district. The submitted plan and any exempted gatherings should adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 3".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025711/https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-3-stay-healthy-guidelines/

name: Illinois
notes_C1: On May 15th, Gov. Pritzker planned to use $225 million on COVID19 testing programs for students who will be returning to middle and high schools in the fall. The covidSHIELD saliva test will be used on campus and results are returned in 12-24 hours. Schools will be fully open next fall.     "Testing will help quickly identify individuals who are positive for COVID-19 so that people who are close contacts of that individual can be quarantined to prevent further spread. This could include exposure in school, sports, or other extra-curricular activities. The more quickly a case can be identified, the number of potential exposures to other people can be reduced, as well as the number of people needing to quarantine."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514223816/https://chicago.suntimes.com/coronavirus/2021/5/12/22432320/illinois-coronavirus-school-testing-vaccine-cases-deaths-reopen-pritzker-covid-19-may-12
notes_C2: Workplace closing remains the same.
notes_C3: Public events remain the same.
notes_C4: Gathering remains the same.
notes_C5: No mention of closing public transit, but: People riding on public transit must comply with Social Distancing Requirements to the greatest extent feasible (stated in executive order by Governor of Illinois).   http://archive.vn/YBkdo
notes_C6: Home requirements remain the same.
notes_C7: On May 10,  anyone traveling from a state on the Orange list is directed to obtain a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Chicago or quarantine for a 10-day period (or the duration of their time in Chicago, whichever is shorter).    Yellow list: Oklahoma, Mississippi, New Mexico, Arkansas, Louisiana, Nevada, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Wyoming, Missouri, Hawaii, Utah, Arizona, Texas, Kentucky, Idaho, Montana, Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, South Dakota, Maryland, Nebraska, Ohio, South Carolina, Virginia, Vermont, Alaska, Connecticut, District of Columbia, and Iowa    Orange list: New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island, Florida, Delaware,  Colorado, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Minnesota, Michigan, Indiana, West Virginia, Maine, North Dakota, Puerto Rico, North Carolina, Oregon, and Washington    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510170155/https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/sites/covid-19/home/emergency-travel-order.html

This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 5 Executive Order 2021-05 was issued, extending, among other orders, EO 2020-20, related to public assistance benefits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402150126/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx
notes_E2: On March 18, 2021, the Illinois Commerce Commission unanimously approved consumer protection agreements to help electric, natural gas, water, and sewer residential customers hard hit by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic to mitigate outstanding consumer debt and prevent disconnections before the winter moratorium on disconnections expires on March 31, 2021. Consumers struggling to pay their energy bill must call the utility to receive benefits and prevent disconnection.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402151910/https://www.icc.illinois.gov/home/covid-19
notes_H1: On May 15th, Gov. Pritzker planned to use $225 million on COVID19 testing programs for students who will be returning to middle and high schools in the fall. The covidSHIELD saliva test will be used on campus and results are returned in 12-24 hours.     "Testing will help quickly identify individuals who are positive for COVID-19 so that people who are close contacts of that individual can be quarantined to prevent further spread. This could include exposure in school, sports, or other extra-curricular activities. The more quickly a case can be identified, the number of potential exposures to other people can be reduced, as well as the number of people needing to quarantine."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514223816/https://chicago.suntimes.com/coronavirus/2021/5/12/22432320/illinois-coronavirus-school-testing-vaccine-cases-deaths-reopen-pritzker-covid-19-may-12
notes_H2: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has several mobile testing teams that are dispatched to various locations around the state each week to provide COVID-19 testing.  Anyone can be tested, regardless of symptoms or immigration status.  There is no cost to the individual for testing, but they should bring their insurance card if they have one.  However, insurance is not required.  Specimens will be collected using a simple nasal swab.  Drive-through and walk-up testing are both available at most locations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190906/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22977
notes_H3: In Illinois, contact tracing is primarily carried out by local health department (LHD) staff. Based on contact tracing data provided by the Department of Public Health, most regions of the state have successfully interviewed at least half of all positive cases and their close contacts (positive cases: some as high as 90%; Region 11 is very low at 0.26%. Close contacts reached ranges between 44-92% across the regions).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322191727/https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/contact-tracing-data?DV=1
notes_H6: On May 15th, Gov. Pritzker will follow the new CDC guideline that vaccinated people will not be required to wear mask in public.    "Spokespeople for the city of Chicago also indicated they will broadly follow the new guidance, though there may be some additional categories in which mask-wearing for vaccinated people will be expected to continue."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210515064515/https://abc7chicago.com/new-cdc-guidelines-for-masks-guidance-on-chicago-mask-mandate-do-we-still-have-to-wear-in-illinois/10633228/
notes_H7: On April 23rd, Illinois resumed administration of J&J vaccine.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503060029/http://www.dph.illinois.gov/news/illinois-department-public-health-resumes-use-johnson-johnson-covid-19-vaccine

name: Indiana
notes_C1: As of May 3, schools in Indiana are offering in-person learning and a hybrid learning model. Many schools in Indiana are planning for extended summer schools options, due to the pandemic to address learning loss from the pandemic.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503163202/https://in.chalkbeat.org/2021/4/23/22399658/to-address-covid-learning-loss-indianapolis-public-schools-expands-summer-school-options
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210506120134/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509063451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: On May 1, Gov Holcomb issued the Executive Order 21-12 which is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. As of May 3, this order is still in effect and is due to expire on 31 May 2021. This order states that "local health departments based on the overall spread of COVID-19 within their community or based the color-coded metric for the county, may impose measures and restrictions on gatherings and events, including limiting the size of social gatherings or event by over attendance". While local authorities may still impose restrictions, there are no longer state wide restrictions on public events as set out in previous orders.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503162931/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/
notes_C4: On May 1, Gov Holcomb issued the Executive Order 21-12 which is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. As of May 3, this order is still in effect and is due to expire on 31 May 2021. This order states that "local health departments based on the overall spread of COVID-19 within their community or based the color-coded metric for the county, may impose measures and restrictions on gatherings and events, including limiting the size of social gatherings or event by over attendance". While local authorities may still impose restrictions on limiting the size of social gatherings, it is no longer mandated by the state. However, Hoosiers are still advised in this order to maintain social distancing when mixing with people outside their household and exercise caution at all times.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503162931/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 4T (from 2T) because the City of Bloomington still limits private gatherings to 15 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210428041847/https://bloomington.in.gov/covid-19
notes_C5: As of March 29, there are no policies that are directed at closing public transport.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224943/https://www.in.gov/indot/2436.htm
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On Tuesday, May 11, Gov. Eric Holcomb (R) issued an order reinstating the requirement that people on unemployment insurance submit weekly reports showing they’ve been actively looking for work. The requirement takes effect June 1. Holcomb waived the job search requirement at the start of the pandemic.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512072104/https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/indiana-restoring-work-search-rule-for-jobless-benefits/2507797/
notes_E2: As of January 4, 2021, according to the Indiana Housing & Community Development website, the rental assistance measures using federal funds were still in effect. Source: https://archive.vn/wqJ4c
notes_H1: As of May 3, the state is still operating a coordinated public health campaign.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142551/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/
notes_H2: As of May 3, Indiana is still running a comprehensive testing system. Hoosiers do not have to be symptomatic in order to get a test. These tests can be obtained can free of charge at community testing sites and tests can be obtained from local health care providers.      Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326211459/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/2524.htm
notes_H3: As of May 3, the Indiana Department of Health is still running a comprehensive contact tracing system.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143159/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: Although the statewide mask mandate was rescinded in mid-April, it was reinstated by local legislatures in some areas, such as Indianapolis, this week. It is now required in all indoor public spaces outside the home, even if for those who are fully vaccinated.     Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516160351/https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/indiana/articles/2021-05-11/indianapolis-officials-back-mask-mandate-capacity-limits  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516160437/https://www.indystar.com/story/news/health/2021/05/14/when-where-you-still-need-wear-mask-central-indiana/5088787001/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516160602/https://www.indystar.com/story/news/health/2021/05/13/indianapolis-mask-mandate-update-cdc-guidelines-covid-19-vaccine/5080675001/
notes_H7: As of April 12, anyone over the age of 16 is eligible for a vaccine since the vaccination eligibility was expanded on March 31. Anyone younger than 18 must receive the Pfizer vaccine. (Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson).     Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210511093207/https://www.indystar.com/story/news/health/2021/04/24/covid-19-vaccine-indiana-johnson-johnson-side-effects/7367759002/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411060906/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/vaccine/

name: Kansas
notes_C1: See note for April 6th
notes_C2: On May 12th 2021, Governor Kelly announced the reopening of state agencies beginning June 13th 2021, as detailed here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516150347/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-state-agency-reopening-guidance/
notes_C3: No obvious change in state-level policy from this date until 02 May 2021 - everything still appears to be done at County level. From April 14th, Lawrence and Douglas Counties will permit events, at venues >50% of minimum capacity. I suspect we ought to change this to 1T, but with no state-level policy change to go on, I am reluctant to take this step  Douglas County reopening policy: https://web.archive.org/web/20210417103905/https://coronavirus-response-dgco.hub.arcgis.com/  Douglas County Health Order: https://web.archive.org/web/20210417103042/https://ldchealth.org/DocumentCenter/View/3772/EMERGENCY-ORDER-OF-LOCAL-HEALTH-OFFICER---April-14---final    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 1T (from 2T). notes_E1: It is not at all clear to me whether the scheme this coding originally referred to is still in place, but as I am struggling to find evidence either way, I thought it best not to change the coding without seeing any clear change in policy. notes_H1: On March 31st 2021, Governor Kelly's press office noted that the State 'recently launched a 'Know Before You Go' campaign to remind Kansans that testing continues to be available'  Governor Kelly's announcement: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403162604/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-no-cost-covid-19-testing-extended-through-end-of-2021/
notes_H2: Free tests still appear to be generally available, as they are planned to be until the end of the year  KDHE testing page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502125345/https://www.coronavirus.kdheks.gov/280/COVID-19-Testing
notes_H3: Kansas claims to have spent $1.6m on contact tracing  Full details of how Kansas has spent its $1bn of the Coronavirus Relief fund can be found here, though it is extremely difficult to know how to code it: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322172010/https://covid.ks.gov/covid-data/
notes_H6: On May 16th, the CDC update their guidelines stating:   "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic.  Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: On May 13th, 2021, Governor Kelly announced that the Pfizer vaccine had been approved for use on those aged 12+, meaning that all Kansas over the age of 12 are eligible to be vaccinated.  As of the 16th May 2021, 902,758 Kansans, around 30% of the population, are fully vaccinated and 1,162,46 Kansas had recieved a first dose (including those who have recieved both doses).    Vaccination figures: https://web.archive.org/web/20210513175430/https://www.kansasvaccine.gov/158/Data  Governor Kelly's Press Release: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516154320/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-now-available-to-ages-12-in-kansas/  KDHE vaccine availability page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210513195916/https://www.kansasvaccine.gov/157/Availability

notes_H2: Testing remains free and widely available.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421005100/https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-covid-testing

notes_H6: Facial coverings are no longer required at outdoor gatherings of fewer than 1000 people. They are still required in all indoor public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2021/04/26/andy-beshear-kentucky-coronavirus-mask-mandate-eased/7389759002/

name: Louisiana
notes_C1: no policy change. I am keeping the code the same at 2T until there there is explicit sources saying that certain schools (particularly required closing to phased re-opening of high school level) has changed.    LSU remains open with this announcement: " Since the COVID-19 vaccine is now readily available, and cases of the virus continue to decline both nationally and in Louisiana, our goal is to operate in-person this fall. In anticipation of that, we are asking each campus unit to be staffed in-person beginning June 1. We know that many of you are still working remotely, and that returning to campus full-time requires some advance notice and planning. Department heads should be planning now for how their unit will be staffed as of June 1. As a reminder, LSU now has a remote work policy, which can be utilized by department heads to make arrangements for their individual units. In accordance with the policy, any arrangements to work remotely must be approved by an employee’s supervisor and unit head."     Current info on NOLA PS: Parents can decide whether to send their children to school in person or keep learning online on a quarterly basis.    Depending on the individual school, between 20 and 30 percent of elementary and middle school students are still learning entirely online, according to district spokesperson Taslin Alfonzo. She said high school students are even more likely to be learning online. Right now it’s closer to a 50-50 split.   More than 70 percent of Louisiana students are currently learning in-person full-time, according to the state department of education’s tracker. Another 20 percent are entirely virtual. About 9 percent of students are in a hybrid model and split their time between online and in-person instruction.    could not archive: https://www.lsu.edu/roadmap/messages/2021-04-29-return-to-campus.php    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516212321if_/https://www.wwno.org/education/2021-04-07/covid-19-cases-associated-with-new-orleans-public-schools-remain-low-despite-loosened-restrictions   (published April 7, 2021)

notes_H2: no policy change.     Mobile testing for COVID-19 in Southwest Louisiana will now include two locations, both with access to rapid COVID-19 testing through Cue Health. Cue offers COVID-19 molecular point-of-care testing with results in 20 minutes. Both sites will continue to offer laboratory molecular testing through the Louisiana Department of Health Lab or Quest Diagnostics. notes_H6: NOTE: code will remain at 2 due to the fact the statewide mask mandate has been lifted but is required in certain settings, regardless of new guidance from CDC mentioned below.     "Today, Gov. John Bel Edwards announced that based on the recommendations by the CDC and in consultation with the Louisiana Dept. of Health, those who are fully vaccinated no longer have to wear masks indoors except in certain situations including: educational facilities, public transit, correctional settings, and health care facilities as regulated by LDH. This is in addition to recent guidance that also eased restrictions on masks outdoors for those who are fully vaccinated. Businesses may decide whether to continue requiring patrons to wear masks and are not limited by the revised proclamation. Further, local governments will continue to be able to make decisions to have further restrictions, including face covering requirements, in place."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210514214200/https://gov.louisiana.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/3126
notes_H7: no policy change.     Louisianans ages 12 and up can now receive the COVID-19 vaccine, following the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) action late Wednesday formally recommending the use of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for this age group. Prior to this announcement, the Pfizer vaccine was recommended and authorized for people no younger than 16 years of age.    State Health Officer Dr. Joseph Kanter said the vaccine has now passed the same safety benchmarks for this younger age group as it did for those ages 16 and older. The Louisiana Department of Health on Thursday morning alerted vaccine providers that they can begin administering the Pfizer vaccine to people ages 12 and up. This updated guidance goes into effect immediately.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210513203846/https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/6161

name: Massachusetts
notes_C1: On April 21, 2021 Governor Baker issued an extension on the closing of all public and private K-12 schools in the state until June 29th.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210519004007/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-state-of-emergency
notes_C2: On May 7th, 2021 Governor Baker issued a statement allowing for Phase IV industries to begin reopening at 50% capacity as of May 10th, with the expectation that there will also be other safety measures in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210519004007/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-state-of-emergency
notes_C3: Governor Baker announced on April 27, 2021 that effective May 10th the state was moving to Phase IV, Step 2. This increases capacity at large venues from 12% to 25%. Amusement parks, theme parks, and water parks are now open and work at 50% capacity, so long as they have health policy measures in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210519010016/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-announces-plans-for-continued-reopening
notes_C4: As of March 18, 2021 Governor Baker had limits on indoor, private gatherings at 10 individuals or fewer. This policy remains in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210519004007/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-state-of-emergency
notes_C5: No change.    "Due to the COVID-19 outbreak, many transit authorities have made adaptations to their regular routes, schedules, and procedures. If you plan to make a trip by public transit, please check your transit authority's website or social media accounts to get the most up-to-date information.    In accordance with the Governor's Order, all passengers over age 5 must wear a face mask while riding public transit and paratransit services, with exceptions made for certain medical conditions and disabilities. Masks are also recommended for passengers ages 2 through 5."    Source:  https://archive.vn/nC3Dp
notes_C6: No new stay at home advisory found.    Source:  https://archive.vn/bfBiI
notes_C7: No change.    "As of Monday, March 22, all visitors entering Massachusetts, including returning residents, are advised to quarantine for 10 days upon their arrival.  Travelers in the following categories are exempt from this quarantine advisory:    Travelers who have received a negative COVID-19 result on a test administered not more than 72 hours prior to their arrival in Massachusetts.  Travelers may also test out of the quarantine advisory after arrival in Massachusetts, as long as they quarantine until receiving a negative test result.  Anyone who is entering Massachusetts for fewer than 24 hours  Anyone who is returning to Massachusetts after being out of the State for fewer than 24 hours  Workers who enter Massachusetts to perform critical infrastructure functions (as specified by the Federal Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency) during required commuting to or from work and while at work.  Travelers who are fully vaccinated (i.e. who have received two doses of either the Moderna or Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines OR who have received a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 14 days or more ago) and who do not have symptoms."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518133103/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: No change.    "Utility companies are prohibited from shutting off electric, gas, and water service during the COVID-19 emergency. However, this does not mean your utilities are free, and any unpaid amount will continue to accrue."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210422231111/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/financial-assistance-during-the-covid-19-crisis
notes_H1: No change to code. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://archive.vn/FfeWO
notes_H2: No change.    "Visit Find a COVID-19 Test to search for a testing site near you.    Many sites may require pre-screening, a referral and/or an appointment. Please contact the site prior to arrival.    Learn about the free drive-through Express COVID-19 Testing Sites in Massachusetts."    Source:  https://archive.vn/6mreQ
notes_H3: No change.    "The Commonwealth of Massachusetts created the COVID-19 Community Tracing program to help support local health departments from every community in their contact tracing work. The program focuses on reaching out to people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and the contacts they have been close to, making sure they have the support they need to isolate or quarantine. When the MA COVID Team calls, you can do your part by answering the phone and providing helpful information that will help flatten and reduce the curve in Massachusetts."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516132508/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/learn-about-the-community-tracing-collaborative
notes_H6: "Today, the Baker-Polito Administration announced that the Commonwealth is on track to meet the goal of vaccinating 4.1 million residents by the first week of June and all remaining COVID-19 restrictions will be lifted effective May 29.    The Commonwealth’s face covering order will also be rescinded on May 29. The Department of Public Health will issue a new face covering advisory consistent with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s updated guidance. Face coverings will still be mandatory for all individuals on public and private transportation systems (including rideshares, livery, taxi, ferries, MBTA, Commuter Rail and transportation stations), in healthcare facilities and in other settings hosting vulnerable populations, such as congregate care settings.    Governor Charlie Baker will end the State of Emergency June 15.     The Administration also announced updates that will be effective May 18 to revise face covering requirements for youth and amateur sports and other guidance relating to childcare programs and K-12 schools. The Administration will release updated guidance for summer camps effective May 29."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210519024416/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-to-lift-covid-restrictions-may-29-state-to-meet-vaccination-goal-by-beginning-of-june
notes_H7: "Beginning Monday, May 10th, six of the Commonwealth’s mass vaccination sites will open for walk up vaccination. These sites include the Hynes Convention Center, the Reggie Lewis Center in Roxbury, the Double Tree in Danvers, the former Circuit City in Dartmouth, the Eastfield Mall in Springfield and the Natick Mall. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210519023133/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-announces-new-walk-up-options-at-mass-vaccination-sites-provides-weekly-dose-update

name: Maryland
notes_C1: As of May 4, 2021, there has been no policy change. “Washington County Public Schools has been in the fourth phase of its “Return to Learn” plan since Feb. 16. In this phase, students are able to attend in-person classes five days a week while distance learning is offered to those who do not wish to return to the classroom yet.” Additionally, there are currently 43 schools in the state reporting COVID-19 outbreaks.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504200131if_/https://www.heraldmailmedia.com/story/news/education/2021/04/24/md-schools-face-covid-cases-as-students-return-to-classrooms/43741917/
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210506120134/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509063451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: As of May 4, 2021, there has been no policy change. This indicator remains coded as 1G.
notes_C4: As of May 15, 2021, "Governor Larry Hogan today announced the lifting of all capacity restrictions on outdoor entertainment, art, and sports venues and indoor entertainment venues and conventions, and all remaining restrictions on indoor and outdoor dining." Thus, this policy has been downgraded to 0.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516220402/https://governor.maryland.gov/2021/05/12/governor-hogan-lifts-capacity-limits-on-indoor-and-outdoor-venues-all-remaining-restrictions-on-indoor-and-outdoor-dining-as-of-may-15/
notes_C5: As of May 5, 2021, there has been no policy change. According to the Maryland Transit Authority website, all services are running, though facial coverings and social distancing are required on public transport. This indicator remains coded as 0.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210505195457/https://www.mta.maryland.gov/coronavirus
notes_C6: As of May 4, 2021, there has been no policy change. This indicator remains coded as 1G.
notes_C7: As of May 4, 2021, there has been no policy change. This indicator remains coded as 1G.
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The Maryland RELIEF Act, which was signed into law on 15th February 2021, provides direct stimulus payments to low- and middle-income Maryland families. As these stimulus payments comprise $500 for families and $300 for individuals, this indicator moves to 1A.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503155324/https://www.marylandtaxes.gov/reliefact/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210503155707/https://governor.maryland.gov/reliefact/
notes_E2: Original note from Jay Harley:    As of February 15th 2021, financial relief remains in place under the updated Maryland RELIEF act, including several provisions intended to provide immediate economic relief to eligible Maryland residents and small businesses, including state-issued "economic impact" stimulus payments for low and moderate-income taxpayers. Webpage here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301222345/https://www.dllr.state.md.us/finance/consumers/frcovid.shtml
notes_H1: Maryland's ongoing COVID-19 public information campaign can be seen in, among other things, its state Twitter account.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503153743/https://twitter.com/MDHealthDept/status/1252601186454245377
notes_H2: The Covid-19 Testing in Maryland webpage indicates that testing is still widespread in the state. On 29th April 2021, a two-week mobile testing programme began to operate at two Walmart stores in Salisbury and Hagerstown. "Free rapid point-of-care (POC) antigen testing, with PCR confirmatory results, will be offered without appointments needed. This is part of a two-week pilot to increase testing opportunities in underserved areas nationwide."     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503160126/https://coronavirus.maryland.gov/pages/symptoms-testing
notes_H3: From Maryland's covidLINK homepage, it appears that contact tracing is still in effect in the state as of 27th April 2021, although it is unclear exactly how effective it is.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210427214139/https://covidlink.maryland.gov/content/answer-the-call/
notes_H6: On May 16th, the CDC update their guidelines stating:   "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic.  Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: As of May 13, 2021, all Marylanders aged 12-15 are additionally eligible to receive a vaccine, according to the Governor's office. Thus, all residents age 12 and above can receive vaccinations in the state. This policy remains coded as 5G to reflect this.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518134226/https://governor.maryland.gov/2021/05/12/governor-hogan-lifts-capacity-limits-on-indoor-and-outdoor-venues-all-remaining-restrictions-on-indoor-and-outdoor-dining-as-of-may-15/

name: Maine
notes_C1: The May 7th assessment of Maine's counties rated all of them as green except for Androscoggin. A yellow rating does not necessarily mean that a school has to switch over to remote learning, but that they "may consider hybrid instructional models". Given this, this indicator remains at 1G. The next assessment will be on May 21, 2021.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518070929/https://www.maine.gov/doe/framework/part-I/
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210506120134/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509063451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: There are several guidelines in place for event organizers to consider when planning public events; however, cancelling the public events is not required.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518071930/https://www.maine.gov/decd/checklists/large-gatherings-ticketed
notes_C4: As of 11th May 2021, Maine's restrictions on indoor and outdoor gatherings are still in place. On 26th March 2021, the limit for indoor gatherings was set to 50%, and the limit for outdoor gatherings was set to 75%. They are due to change on 24th May 2021.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518072026/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/moving-maine-forward
notes_C5: As of 11th May 2021, the Greater Portland Metro system is running, with requirements that passengers and staff wear face coverings over both the mouth and nose at all times.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518072156/https://gpmetro.org/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=63
notes_C6: As of 11th May 2021, it is still recommended that those at greatest risk from COVID-19 limit their time outside the home.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518071345/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_C7: Starting on 1st May 2021, Maine no longer requires proof of a negative test or quarantine for travelers to the state; however, face masks and physical distancing are still required.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518072501/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/keepmainehealthy/faqs
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: As of 11th May 2021, Maine's Emergency Rental Assistance Program is still running. Therefore this indicator remains at 1.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518072605/https://www.mainehousing.org/programs-services/rental/rentaldetail/covid-19-rental-relief-program
notes_H1: As of 11th May 2021, Maine's COVID-19 homepage continues to provide information to the public.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518071345/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_H2: As of 11th May 2021, COVID-19 testing is still widely available in Maine, with anybody over the age of 12 months able to get a test without a physician's referral.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518071345/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_H3: As of 11th May 2021, it appears that Maine's contact tracing system is still in operation.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516203924/https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/infectious-disease/epi/airborne/coronavirus/contact-tracing.shtml
notes_H6: On 27th April 2021, Governor Janet Mills announced that Maine residents are no longer required to wear a mask outdoors, based on CDC recommendations that the risk of transmission outdoors is low. Masks are still required indoors, however.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517115445/https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/maine-updates-public-health-guidance-use-face-coverings-outdoor-public-settings-2021-04-27
notes_H7: As of 11th May 2021, Maine is now administering vaccinations to all people age 12+.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210511162045/https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/mills-administration-statement-fdas-authorization-pfizers-covid-19-vaccine-12-15-year-olds

name: Michigan
notes_C1: As of May 17, many school districts in Michigan are offering in-person, remote learning or hybrid learning options. The Novi Community School District is offering full-time in person teaching 5 days a week whereas the Detroit Public School district still has a "pause" on in-person learning due to case numbers.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210511094751/https://detroit.chalkbeat.org/2021/5/10/22429518/detroit-school-board-reschedules-meeting-where-it-will-decide-on-suspending-in-person-learning    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517114822/https://www.theoaklandpress.com/news/coronavirus/novi-schools-returning-to-full-time-in-person-learning/article_4e451cb2-77a7-11eb-adbd-43d91b81b77d.html
notes_C2: As of May 17, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) issued the "Gatherings and Face Mask Order". This order remains in effect through May 31, 2021, at 11:59 PM. Regarding workplace closings, it states that "Venues and activities held at those venues comply with masking and distancing requirements in this subsection. Venues that cannot consistently adhere to these requirements (e.g., water parks, dance floors at a nightclub, or children's indoor playgrounds inasmuch as staff are not present to prevent physical contact) may not be open". Gov. Whitmore also recommends that people who can work form home should keep doing so, but in two weeks time in the next stage of the re-opening plan some of these sectors can return to work.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210509035050/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455_98456_103043-558489--,00.html     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517121053/https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/michigan/2021/05/12/live-stream-gov-whitmer-provides-michigan-covid-update/
notes_C3: As of May 17, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) "Gatherings and Face Mask Order" is still in effect .This order will remain in effect remains in effect through May 31, 2021, at 11:59 PM. This order outlines restrictions on both indoor and outdoor events as follows:     -Indoor gatherings: Are prohibited at residential venues, except where no more than 15 persons from no more than 3 households are gathered; Are prohibited at non-residential venues, except where no more than 25 persons are gathered.  - Outdoor gatherings are permitted only as follows: At residential venues, where 50 persons are gathered. Or, where density does not exceed 20 persons per 1,000 square feet of outdoor space, up to 300 persons may be gathered; At non-residential venues, where 300 or fewer persons are gathered.     This restrictions will impact public events and the order states "As a condition of hosting a gathering under this order, organizers and facilities must design the gathering to encourage and maintain physical distancing, and must ensure that persons not part of the same group maintain 6 feet of distance from one another to the extent possible."     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210509035050/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455_98456_103043-558489--,00.html
notes_C4: As of May 17, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) "Gatherings and Face Mask Order" is still in effect and will remain in effect through May 31, 2021, at 11:59 PM. This order outlines restrictions on both indoor and outdoor events as follows:     -Indoor gatherings: Are prohibited at residential venues, except where no more than 15 persons from no more than 3 households are gathered; Are prohibited at non-residential venues, except where no more than 25 persons are gathered.  - Outdoor gatherings are permitted only as follows: At residential venues, where 50 persons are gathered. Or, where density does not exceed 20 persons per 1,000 square feet of outdoor space, up to 300 persons may be gathered; At non-residential venues, where 300 or fewer persons are gathered.     This is coded as 3G to reflect the restrictions on the indoor event gatherings.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210509035050/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455_98456_103043-558489--,00.html
notes_C5: As of May 17, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) "Gatherings and Face Mask Order" remains in effect through May 31, 2021, at 11:59 PM. As a condition of gathering for the purpose of transportation, the order states that transportation providers must require all staff and patrons to use face masks, and must enforce physical distancing among all patrons to the extent feasible.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210509035050/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455_98456_103043-558489--,00.html
notes_C6: As of April 5, there is no mandated stay at home requirements but the MDHHS still reminds people that socialising with people outside your home is risky and that precautions should be taken.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405132414/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus
notes_C7: As of May 17, the MDHSS still recommends to delay travel if possible as travel increases the risk of spreading the virus.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210516215851/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA) and Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation (PEUC) are extended through September 4, 2021. Pandemic Unemployment Compensation, the additional $300 per week for anyone receiving unemployment benefits, according to the Michigan Department of Labor and Economic Opportunity's Unemployment Insurance Agency.   In late February, the U.S. Dept. of Labor issued guidance expanding PUA eligibility to include three COVID-19 related reasons under which an individual may self-certify when directly affected by COVID-19 including:  "Individuals who refuse to return to work that is unsafe or to accept an offer of new work that is unsafe (meaning it is not in compliance with local, state or national health and safety standards directly related to COVID-19) Certain individuals who provide services to educational institutions or educational service agencies and are fully or partially unemployed as a direct result of COVID-19. Individuals experiencing a reduction of hours or a temporary or permanent layoff as a direct result of COVID-19. The additional eligibility provisions apply retroactively to the beginning of the PUA program for those who filed before Dec. 27, 2020."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419232201/https://www.michigan.gov/leo/0,5863,7-336-94422_97241---,00.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419232504/https://www.michigan.gov/leo/0,5863,7-336-94422_97241_89982_92608_63224_105333---,00.html
notes_E2: Rental assistance is available for Michiganders. The City of Detroit implemented a water shutoff moratorium that is in effect until 2022. A temporary statewide ban on water shutoffs at occupied homes arising from unpaid bills is set to automatically expire on March 31. No other formal moratoriums on utility shutoffs have been issued by the state. The Michigan Public Service Commission ended other utility shutoff protections in July 2020. The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has issued payments to the accounts of low-income customers to help them continue paying their energy bills during the coronavirus pandemic. Individuals may be eligible for utility assistance via CERA. Mortgage/Foreclosure Relief: The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services offers homeowners up to $2,000 in emergency assistance with mortgage payments, property taxes, and other housing-related items.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233448/https://www.michiganradio.org/post/water-shutoff-moratorium-ends-march-31-extension-possible  https://www.justia.com/covid-19/50-state-covid-19-resources/eviction-mortgage-foreclosure-relief-during-covid-19-50-state-resource/#michigan
notes_H1: As of May 17, the MDHHS is operating a comprehensive coordinated public campaign and updates their website regularly.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510180300/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_104699_104714-554722--,00.html
notes_H2: As of May 17, the MDHHS is still providing tests to anyone who wants one. Community Pop-up testing sites are free and open to the public. Many of these are executed in partnership with Michigan's Intermediate School Districts (ISDs), school districts, local health departments, churches, and other important community organizations. These events are open to all, including but not limited to educators, students, and community members.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510180300/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_104699_104714-554722--,00.html
notes_H3: As of May 17, the MDHHS is still operating a comprehensive contact tracing system.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510180838/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus
notes_H6: As of May 17, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) "Gatherings and Face Mask Order" remains in effect through May 31, 2021, at 11:59 PM. This order states that "All persons participating in gatherings are required to wear a face mask" which exceptions being made in the following circumstances:   -Are younger than 2 years old;  -Cannot medically tolerate a face mask;  -Are eating or drinking while seated in a designated area or at a private residence;  -Are participating in non-contact sports practice or competition outdoors;  -Are swimming  -Are receiving a medical or personal care service for which removal of the face mask is necessary;  -Are asked to temporarily remove a face mask for identification purposes;  -Are communicating with someone who is deaf, deafblind, or hard of hearing and whose ability to see the mouth is essential to communication  -Are actively engaged in a public safety role, including but not limited to law enforcement, firefighters, or emergency medical personnel, and where wearing a face mask would seriously interfere in the performance of their public safety responsibilities  -Are engaging in a religious service  -Are giving a speech for broadcast or to an audience, provided that the audience is at least 12 feet away from the speaker;   -Are participating in a testing program specified in the MDHHS publication entitled Interim Guidance for Athletics issued May 4, 2021, and are engaged in practice or competition where the wearing of a mask would be unsafe;  -Are engaging in an activity that requires removal of a mask not listed in another part of this section, and are in a facility that provides ventilation that meets or exceeds 60 ft3/min of outdoor airflow per person;  -Are at a residential gathering, and are fully vaccinated and not experiencing the principal symptoms of COVID-19;  -Are at an outdoor gathering with fewer than 100 persons, unless otherwise required to mask as an organized sport participant under Section 6(a).    This mask mandate remains in effect despite the CDC's recent recommendation that masks are no longer required indoors and outdoors if you're fully vaccinated.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210509035050/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455_98456_103043-558489--,00.html     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517122654/https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/michigan/2021/05/13/michigans-mask-mandate-still-in-effect-despite-new-cdc-guidelines/
notes_H7: As of May 17, vaccines are universally available in Michigan (Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson and Johnson). All Michiganders over the age of 12 are eligible to be vaccinated with an age appropriate vaccine. Individuals 12 years and older must receive the Pfizer vaccine only.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210516152408/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_103214---,00.html

name: Missouri
notes_C1: Original Note by Veronique Gauthier: On March 24, the University of Missouri published a press release about workers. Dear University faculty and staff,    Throughout this last year, you have proven yourselves resilient in a time of great uncertainty and steady change. We so appreciate your willingness to step up and keep us going.    Thankfully, effective – and increasingly available – COVID-19 vaccines, along with a decrease in active cases in our region, usher in new possibilities for how we can interact.    Next Monday (March 29), all of you, as higher education faculty and staff (including student employees), will be eligible to receive a COVID-19 vaccine. We strongly encourage you to sign up for a vaccine appointment. Please see our vaccine page here for links to options, which includes information to make an appointment as dates become available at our Faurot Field vaccine site. There, dedicated MU Health Care teams have already vaccinated nearly 23,000 people.    Over the last several months, many of you safely returned to in-person work, following our COVID-19 guidelines. Meanwhile in our community, public schools have announced plans to shift to full in-person attendance in early April and this week, Boone County relaxed public health orders. We expect this progress to continue as we approach fall and our plans to resume full-capacity classes and activities here at Mizzou.    As another step toward resuming our pre-pandemic lives, we ask faculty and staff who have not yet returned to in-person work to do so by May 17. Faculty on 9-month appointments without duties over the summer should plan to return in August. We are sending this message in advance to give you and your supervisor time to make a transition plan if needed.    As more faculty and staff return, we remain committed to sustaining a safe community. Social distancing and face covering requirements will continue until public health guidance changes. Supervisors will need to ensure work settings meet office safety expectations and consult with Campus Facilities if work spaces need modification.    We know ongoing efforts to maximize our resources, including the recent announcement to close buildings, mean some in-person offices will not be the same. In addition, we realize, in some settings, social distancing is not possible with a full in-person return and that factor should be considered in any transition plan. If you witness an unsafe situation at work related to our COVID-19 protocols, you should let your supervisor know or submit a concern here.    Through this transition, we expect to retain some of our COVID-era practices, as we found some enhanced our work. In some circumstances, supervisors may decide flexible work arrangements will best fit the environment and the work needed to support the university’s mission. If so, your supervisor will initiate, revise or extend a telework arrangement. The form is available on our Working Through COVID-19 webpage and will need to be submitted by May 17.    We know our Tigers are anxious to enjoy a “more normal” experience in the fall, which will of course adhere to the advice of our medical experts, local public health officials, and CDC guidance. Our Show Me Renewal site will stay current with any changes along the way. There, you can also find the latest updates on the process for planning events. We see this step as a sign of hope for our university as we return to more in-person activity to serve our students, our community, and our state.    Thank you to everyone for your tremendous efforts during this extraordinary time. We are grateful to reach this point and for the rest of our community to join us on our beautiful campus.    Tigers Support Tigers!    Mun Choi, Ph.D.  President, University of Missouri    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330134539/https://president.missouri.edu/messages/full-in-person-work-return-by-5-17/
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. notes_C3: Boone County issued Order No. 2020-21C, and the City of Columbia issued Order No. 2020-21, effective March 24. Sports and sporting events are allowed, but participants must remain in stable groups and spectators must follow social distancing and mask-wearing requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327043037/https://www.como.gov/wp-content/uploads/Health-Order-2020-21c-Boone-County.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210405132729/https://www.como.gov/wp-content/uploads/Health-Order-2020-21-City-of-Columbia.pdf     As of April 4, the latest health order in St. Louis County is still the Fourth Amended Safer At Home Order, which requires any outdoor event at 50% capacity that exceeds 500 people to submit a plan for approval by the Department of Health.    https://archive.fo/hPLLl    The St. Louis Auto Show taking place downtown at America’s Center and the St. Charles Home Show at the St. Charles Convention Center represent two of the earliest large-scale events to return in the area during the COVID-19 era. The show will run from April 10-11.    https://archive.fo/oMkvS    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 1T (from 2T) since sporting events are allowed to occur with COVID-19 precautionary measures. Also, the interpretation guide advises coding at the 1 level if public venues/mass gatherings are limited by percent occupancy restrictions.
