notes_E1: On May 06,Missouri WIC is temporarily increasing the Cash Value Benefit for Fruit and Vegetable Purchases (CVB) to $35 per month for eligible women and children. WIC is the Department of Health and Senior Services Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children.    The American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) gave USDA authority to temporarily increase the CVB during the federally declared COVID-19 public health emergency. Missouri WIC has elected to use this authority from June through September 2021, to provide additional healthy fruits and vegetables for up to 60,000 women and children per month. Standard CVB values range from $9 - $11.  Eligible participants need to contact their WIC local agency to schedule an appointment to load the additional funds on their eWIC card before June 1 to avoid any delays.    WIC families have the opportunity to shop for nutritious foods at over 600 authorized WIC retailers throughout Missouri and can receive services at any of the 118 local agencies. WIC serves financially eligible women, infants, and children under the age of five. Fathers, stepparents, foster parents, grandparents, and guardians are also encouraged to apply for WIC benefits for any children in the household under the age of five.    Missouri WIC provides quality nutrition education, breastfeeding promotion and support, nutritious foods, and referrals to health services. It is also one of the most successful, cost-effective, and important nutrition intervention programs in the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510195740/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/ffc068f3-adcb-4fb0-bd21-8ec6d907eb6e/missouri-wic-temporary-benefit-increase
notes_E2: Mayor Lyda Krewson today announced that City of St. Louis residents who need help staying in their homes and keeping their utilities on during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic can apply for rental and utility assistance through the State of Missouri beginning Thursday, April 1. Since two major cities have rental assistance in place (St. Louis & Kansas City), I have changed the coding from 0 “None” to 1 “Narrow” relief.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405130357/https://www.stlouis-mo.gov/government/departments/mayor/news/rental-utility-assistance-apr-2021.cfm https://archive.fo/O7oVh
notes_H1: As of April 17, Missouri is preparing to launch a $5 million ad campaign to urge residents to get the coronavirus vaccine. Called Stronger Together, the campaign will begin next month and will provide vaccination information through radio, TV, print and social media messages.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417195927/https://ktvo.com/news/local/missouri-to-begin-5m-covid-19-vaccination-campaign
notes_H2: On April 30, testing continues to be one of the most effective tools in the fight to contain the virus that causes COVID-19 and move past the pandemic.      Those who should get tested include those experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, those who have had close contact with someone with confirmed COVID-19 (unless fully vaccinated or tested positive for COVID-19 within the past 3 months), those with household contact, those who have taken part in activities that put them at higher risk of infection, and those who have been recommended for testing by their healthcare provider or health department. Many camps, events and some forms of travel have moved to requiring evidence of a negative test result prior to participation.    Testing capacity has grown significantly over the past year, and testing efforts have continuously evolved to meet existing needs.    Now, there are tests that have been authorized by the FDA for at-home usage. Those who need to be tested for COVID-19 and can’t get tested by a healthcare provider can consider using either a self-collection kit or a self-test that can be performed anywhere. Self-collection kits and tests are available either by prescription or over the counter in a pharmacy or retail store without a prescription. Currently available self-collection kits and tests are used for the detection of current infection. These tests either require a nasal or saliva specimen.    The availability of these tests increases access to testing which results in the ability to take appropriate public health action. However, following the self-collection directions carefully is important for the validity of the result. It is also important to follow directions for reporting of the test results as it ensures the continuity of public health surveillance and mitigation efforts    The State continues to offer community testing events in areas throughout the state in a regular weekly cadence. A new regular event in Branson has been added to the schedule. Community testing events are free COVID-19 testing options that are available to anyone without any specific reason needed for the testing.     No pre-registration or appointment is needed, and patients do not need to be Missouri residents to be tested. A government-issued ID is not required, but if available will shorten the onsite registration process. The test used at these community testing events is a PCR test done by an anterior nares swab to determine the presence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Once tested, individuals will be notified of results no later than 72 hours from the end of the testing event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503141703/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/885a067c-2b1c-480a-a270-18333827f2da/more-covid-19-testing-options-increase-accessibility
notes_H3: On May 14,The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS) continues to partner with the Missouri Department of Natural Resources, the University of Missouri – Columbia, wastewater operators, and others to monitor COVID-19 trends by testing wastewater in communities throughout the state.    In February 2021, this team began testing wastewater samples to look for the presence of variants of the virus that causes COVID-19. Using a technique called high throughput sequencing, samples with sufficient COVID-19 genetic material are tested for genetic mutations, which are compared to mutations in known variants. The testing results are now displayed in a new layer of the COVID-19 sewershed surveillance StoryMap.    In press releases issued on February 26 and March 9, DHSS announced initial rounds of this testing, which suggested the B.1.1.7 (UK) variant virus was present in sewage samples in some locations throughout the state.    This sequencing testing now suggests the B.1.1.7 (UK) variant is present in all areas tested across the state. B.1.1.7 is considered a variant of concern in part due to evidence of its increased transmissibility. Other mutations associated with other variants of concern seen by this testing include B1.427/B.1.429 (South California), Brazil, and South African; however, these mutations have tended not to be as consistently present as the B.1.1.7.    Even though these mutations are present, viral load levels remain relatively stable. This stability suggests that efforts to minimize transmission of the virus are working, and stresses the importance of continued testing, vaccinations, and adherence to local recommendations to stop the spread of the virus.    Viruses constantly change through genetic mutation. As the COVID-19 pandemic has progressed, several variants of the COVID-19 virus (SARS-CoV-2) have emerged. Some variants may have a selective advantage due to their specific mutations, which is why some variants can become dominant over the “parent” strain (original strain of the virus). Advantages may include how easily variants spreads from person to person.    For the genetic sequence testing, small sections of the total COVID-19 RNA strand are being analyzed. Because the entire genetic sequences are not being analyzed, the results do not confirm the presence of an actual variant; however, they are suggestive of the presence and distribution of variants across the state. While wastewater testing can be a useful tool for screening for the presence of variants, sequencing of a clinical specimen is required to confirm their presence.    “In some communities, we are consistently detecting the same mutation week after week, serving as a signal of the presence of these correlating variant(s) in the population. In other communities, results are inconsistent between weeks,” said Jeff Wenzel, Bureau Chief of Environmental Epidemiology. “Several reasons could cause this to happen. One possibility is travelers or visitors passing through could be contributing to variation, or person(s) cease shedding after recovery from the infection.”    Despite uncertainties, these results are useful for informing public health investigations and response for stopping the spread of COVID-19. Washing hands, wearing masks, testing, social distancing, and vaccinations have slowed the spread of the virus. The emergence of variants emphasizes the importance to continue efforts to minimize transmission including continued testing, becoming fully vaccinated, and adherence to local recommendations to stop the spread of the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517135131/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/31bcc035-ed09-4d40-976f-fc9136c81c38/dhss-provides-virus-variant-updates-from-wastewater-monitoring-project
notes_H6: As of April 25, Kansas City still requires residents to wear facial coverings in public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426104420/https://www.kcmo.gov/city-hall/departments/health/coronavirus-covid-19-kcmo-information-and-response/reopen
notes_H7: On May 12, Robert Knodell, Acting Director of the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS) and Dr. George Turabelidze, State Epidemiologist, signed the standing order for PfizerBioNTech COVID-19 vaccine administration for individuals 12 to 15 years in the state of Missouri. This is following the decision by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) to recommend to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) that the Pfizer vaccine be made available to administer to children ages 12-15 years. The vaccine is safe and effective in preventing COVID-19. Prior to this decision, the Pfizer vaccine was only approved for individuals age 16 and above.    In Missouri, this expanded authorization creates vaccine eligibility for approximately 313,000 additional individuals.     The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine is administered as a series of two doses, at least three weeks apart, for all eligible individuals. It is important to receive the second dose for maximum protection against COVID-19.    COVID-19 vaccinations for those 12 years and older are available from any provider offering the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. DHSS continues to enroll pediatricians into State’s COVID-19 vaccine program so they can order COVID-19 vaccines and administer them to their patients. Additionally, schools may consider partnering with a local public health agency or other provider to set up vaccination clinics for students.    The Moderna and Janssen/Johnson & Johnson vaccines continue to be available to individuals age 18 and older. Those seeking vaccination should visit MOStopsCovid.com to find vaccination sites and events. State-supported events and vaccination sites can be found at this site. Individuals can also register in Missouri Vaccine Navigator and find appointment options in the following languages: English, Spanish, Chinese, Portuguese and French. Some local providers also accept walk-ins.     In most situations, a parent or guardian must be present for an individual under the age of 18 to receive the vaccine. In some settings, written consent from a parent or guardian may also be permissible.      In clinical trials, the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine was found to be 100% effective in preventing COVID-19 among participants ages 12-15. The side effects in adolescents were similar with those reported in clinical trial participants 16 years of age and older and included pain at the injection site, tiredness, headache, chills, muscle and joint pain, and fever.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517134903/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/25ecab6d-9662-450f-b160-a211aef4170d/dhss-authorizes-pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-administration-for-adolescents

notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html

notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: On April 6, the Governor announced that emergency rent and utility relief is available for residents of Montana:    "Renters can receive a monthly maximum of $2,200 for past due and future rent payments, up to $300 for past due and future utilities including gas and electric, and $50 per month for internet. Households can access assistance dating back to April 1, 2020."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419025437/https://news.mt.gov/emergency-rent-utility-assistance-now-available-for-montanans-financially-impacted-by-covid-19
notes_H1: There is a comprehensive public health campaign.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423035620/https://covid19.mt.gov/
notes_H2: Testing remains prioritized for symptomatic individuals and surveillance testing in health and congregate care settings. However, the guidelines provide for wider testing if capacity allows. No stories the press about difficulties getting tested suggests that capacity is adequate for wide availability.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421004738/https://covid19.mt.gov/Montanas-Testing-Information
notes_H3: Difficult to say because there are no stories or available contract tracing metrics, but the reduced caseload in the state suggests contact tracing is able to work.
notes_H6: Gov. Gianforte signed HB 121 and 230 into law limiting authorities of public health officials by providing elected officials more oversight into emergency declarations. Support for these bills rose from criticisms against public health officials failing to consider impacts on small, local businesses during state emergencies. Public health officials are required to propose health mandates to elected officials first before proceeding to enact and enforce the mandate.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510143655/https://montanafreepress.org/2021/03/01/house-passes-bills-limiting-authority-of-local-health-officials-and-governor/
notes_H7: Vaccinations are available to all persons over 18.  State is administering Moderna, Pfizer and Janssen.  A, B, C.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421095442/https://dphhs.mt.gov/Portals/85/publichealth/documents/HAN/2021/HANUD2021-8.pdf?ver=2021-03-24-134722-073

name: North Carolina
notes_C1: According to the NC DHHS (as of 29 April 2021), "schools should return to in person learning to the greatest extent possible according to plans allowed by the State (Elementary, middle, and high schools can open in Plan A)," even if the school district is in a red or orange tier county. The K-12 Public Health Toolkit outlines social distancing and sanitation requirements for school reopening (last updated 05 May 2021).    Because the extent of return to in person learning is decided by school districts, I am leaving the code 1T (see interpretation guide).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511194612/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/868/download  https://web.archive.org/web/20210505184001/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/164/open
notes_C2: No new updates. Executive Order 209 (effective 30 April 2021 to 01 June 2021) makes no change to existing percent occupancy limits at workplaces such as restaurants, bars, etc (see Executive Order 204).    "Indoors up to 75% and Outdoors up to 100% Capacity, Subject to Masks and 6 ft. Social Distancing: Restaurants, Breweries, Wineries, and Distilleries, Recreation (e.g., bowling, skating, rock climbing), Fitness and Physical Activity Facilities (e.g., gyms, yoga studios, fitness centers), Pools, Amusement Parks."    Press release on EO204 (no longer in effect, but see for more details on occupancy limits):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511202748/https://governor.nc.gov/news/gov-cooper-announces-north-carolina-will-relax-some-covid-19-restrictions%EF%BB%BF  Press release on EO209:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511133458/https://governor.nc.gov/news/gov-cooper-issues-executive-order-relax-state%E2%80%99s-outdoor-mask-mandate-and-ease-mass-gathering  EO209: https://web.archive.org/web/20210509205256/https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf
notes_C3: No new updates. Executive Order 209 (effective 30 April 2021 to 01 June 2021) makes no change to existing percent occupancy limits in large public venues (see Executive Order 204).    "Indoors and Outdoors up to 50% Capacity, Subject to Masks and 6 ft. Social Distancing: Bars, Movie Theaters*, Gaming Facilities*, Meeting, Reception, and Conference Spaces, Lounges (including tobacco) and Night Clubs, Auditoriums, Arenas, and other venues for live performances, Sports Arenas and Fields (includes professional, collegiate, and amateur). *Movie theaters and gaming facilities may operate at up to 75% capacity outdoors."    Press release on EO204 (no longer in effect, but see for more details on occupancy limits):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511202748/https://governor.nc.gov/news/gov-cooper-announces-north-carolina-will-relax-some-covid-19-restrictions%EF%BB%BF  Press release on EO209:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511133458/https://governor.nc.gov/news/gov-cooper-issues-executive-order-relax-state%E2%80%99s-outdoor-mask-mandate-and-ease-mass-gathering  EO209: https://web.archive.org/web/20210509205256/https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO209-Easing-Statewide-Restrictions.pdf

notes_C5: The R-line in Raleigh remains suspended until July (tentative). notes_C6: Individuals in red and orange tier counties are recommended to stay at home if they are at high risk for developing serious disease, and they are encouraged to avoid large groups and settings where people do not wear masks. As of 29 April 2021:  "None of North Carolina’s counties are currently red. There are 30 orange counties,  56 yellow counties, 14 light yellow counties, and no green counties. In comparison, the  previous report posted April 15th showed one red county, 20 orange counties, 48 yellow  counties, 30 light yellow counties, and 1 green county. 56 counties are in the same tier as the previous report. 34 counties have moved up a tier (toward red) since the last report and 10 counties have moved down a tier (toward green)."     Because there are still many orange counties, code remains 1T.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511194612/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/868/download
notes_C7: As of 30 April 2021, the NC DHHS recommends delaying travel plans and staying at home, if possible.  Visitors to North Carolina do not have to quarantine upon arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509091736/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/media/2394/open  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511193143/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/covid-19-travel-resources
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: No found updates.
notes_E2: Ir remains until June 30, 2021.
notes_H1: State-wide public information campaigns (including vaccination appointments) continue on the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (NC DHHS) website and Twitter page.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210511205907/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510223901if_/https://myspot.nc.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210513182434/https://twitter.com/ncdhhs
notes_H2: Continous offering COVID-19 Test. It is focusing on persons with symptoms or suspicious to get COVID-19.    It is no cost, offers a Test Site Finder, Test Home Collection Kit Program, and other ways to have the test kit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210510212946/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/about-covid-19/testing/find-my-testing-place
notes_H3: As of 16 May 2021, there is a decrease in contact tracers from 936 to 923. They have  "There is more than 2,000 full-time and part-time staff supporting contact tracing efforts at the LHD level, including the 923 Community Care of North Carolina (CCNC) contact tracers." Of 923 hired, 348 (38%) are bilingual.    *This web page does not show the number of patients under this system, or if the number of hired are adequate to the NC population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210514021820/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/dashboard/contact-tracing-dashboard
notes_H6: "(...) Based on recommendations from the CDC, face shields do not meet the requirements for face coverings and does not recommend masks intended for healthcare workers, (...)"    https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/information/individuals-families-and-communities/face-coverings-and-masks
notes_H7: > 16+ age are eligible for free vaccination, regardless of immigration status. Pfizer-BioNTech is approved for age 16+,   Moderna and J&J are approved for age 18+.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511134108/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/vaccines  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511134542/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/vaccines/covid-19-vaccines-safety

notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html

This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html

notes_E1: The Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) will be issuing emergency supplemental allotments to Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) recipients who receive benefits for the month of April on May 11. With the passage of the American Rescue Plan Act, the increase in minimum and maximum allotments will continue until September 30, 2021.  https://archive.fo/CEBKx
notes_E2: The CDC eviction moratorium and the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) are still in place (until March 31).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114912/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Energy-Assistance.aspx
notes_H1: On April 28, DHHS continues to share new information via the Coronavirus website, as well as Facebook and Twitter and at virtual town halls. Each week, members of the DHHS team hold a mid-day Facebook Live session to discuss vaccine-related and pandemic-related topics. For those unable to watch live, all sessions are archived and available on the video tab of the DHHS Facebook page  and the DHHS website.    This week, DHHS Chief Executive Officer Dannette Smith and Dr. Emily Patel, a maternal and fetal medicine specialist at Nebraska Methodist Hospital, will discuss COVID-19 vaccines and Women's Health Month at noon on Thursday, April 29.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503131805/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-COVID-19-Weekly-Update-04282021.aspx
notes_H2: As of May 10, Test Nebraska is still in place to provide access to Covid-19 tests for Nebraskan residents.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510180444/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Testing.aspx
notes_H3: On April 12,he Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Nebraska Public Health Lab (NPHL) have confirmed that the New York variant of COVID-19, known as B1.526 has arrived in the state. The initial case has been identified as a Douglas County resident. An investigation is underway and ongoing. The identified B1.526 variant has been spreading throughout the United States, specifically in the Northeast, and is still being studied to determine the level of contagiousness and severity. Testing platforms like Test Nebraska and others will still produce a “positive” result for the identified B1.526 variant (and other variants). It is expected that vaccinations will remain effective.      Nebraska’s Chief Medical Officer Dr. Gary Anthone said, “We have continued to stress that Nebraskans cannot let up on our mitigation efforts and testing remains critical against not only the spread, but preventing another major surge of COVID-19 cases. As these variants continue to be discovered in the state, vaccinations, testing, masking, and distancing remain the best defenses we have in this fight. I strongly encourage that individuals continue to get tested, especially if they have symptoms and have not yet been vaccinated.”    As researchers learn more about this and other variants it remains as important as ever to continue masking, distancing, and avoiding the 3Cs. Get a test if you’re exposed or if you develop symptoms. Register now at vaccinate.ne.gov and get the vaccine when it’s offered to you to help Nebraska FinishStrong.      DHHS and NPHL have been working to increase sequencing capabilities within the state. Higher volumes of in-state sequencing began in January and NPHL currently has capacity to sequence more than 100 specimens per week. Creighton University is also sequencing roughly 100 specimens per week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210413031943/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Nebraska-Identifies-B1-526-Variant-of-COVID-19.aspx
notes_H6: On May 16th, the CDC update their guidelines stating:   "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic.  Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: An intense effort to reach out in partnership with North Omaha’s faith-based community began May 15 with the first of five remote COVID-19 vaccination clinics. All the clinics will offer the Pfizer vaccine, so anyone 12 years of age and older can be vaccinated.  https://archive.fo/ckwNb

notes_C1: Original note by Juliet O'Brien: K-12 schools had to return to in-person learning full-time on April 19, according to the governor.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509162904/https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/gov-sununu-to-give-an-update-on-nhs-covid-19-response/2344555/    Note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: Recoded from 1T to 1G due to lack of changes in policy since 1G coding. 1T or 0 coding justified if schools in certain areas or across the state no longer require COVID modifications
notes_C2: "Universal Best Practices" guidance has health/safety guidelines for businesses if they want to reopen.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509162053/https://www.covidguidance.nh.gov/
notes_C3: "Safer at Home 2.0" guidelines no longer in effect.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509162053/https://www.covidguidance.nh.gov/
notes_C4: No change.
notes_C5: No measures observed.
notes_C6: "Safer at Home 2.0" guidance changed to "Universal Best Practices" guidance on the state website on 8 May.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509162053/https://www.covidguidance.nh.gov/
notes_C7: NH does not require quarantine after interstate travel for asymptomatic individuals.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509162203/https://www.dhhs.nh.gov/dphs/cdcs/covid19/documents/travel-guidance.pdf
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: New Hampshire Emergency Rental Assistance program is receiving applications currently.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509161826/https://www.goferr.nh.gov/
notes_H1: No change.
notes_H2: No change.
notes_H3: No change.
notes_H6: As of April 27th, the mask mandate for federal buildings and recommendations for mask-wearing on public transportation still stand.     The CDC updated its mask-wearing guidance on April 27th for those who have been fully vaccinated, stating:   "You can gather indoors with fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask or staying 6 feet apart."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427062253/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html  See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427035558/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/using-transportation.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426161816/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-the-federal-workforce-and-requiring-mask-wearing/
notes_H7: Vaccine is available to all 16+, with resources on the government website to aid the vulnerable with sign-ups.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210509161405/https://www.vaccines.nh.gov/vaccine-phases

name: New Jersey
notes_C1: The majority of schools are open in some form for in-person learning; however, the state website says, "School closure is a local decision that should be made by school administrators in consultation with local public health officials." Schools must follow the reopening health/safety guidance issued by the state.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518063827/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/are-schools-open-what-are-the-safety-requirements
notes_C2: The New Jersey government has comprehensive guidance on business reopening on their website, including employers' responsibilities to their employees and the health and safety guidance that must be followed if businesses want to be open.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518064021/https://business.nj.gov/covid
notes_C3: Public events are allowed to take place in accordance with state guidelines on gathering limits and reopening guidance.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518064319/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings
notes_C4: General indoor gatherings are limited to 25 people, and general outdoor gatherings are limited to 500 people with social distancing. More specific rules available at the archived source below.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518064319/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings
notes_C5: Public transport mostly running at full capacity, but enhanced cleaning regimes are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518064455/https://www.njtransit.com/covid19
notes_C6: Symptomatic or potentially exposed individuals should self-isolate and stay home; nothing specific recommending asymptomatic individuals to stay home.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518064913/https://covid19.nj.gov/
notes_C7: Unvaccinated individuals are strongly discouraged from non-essential interstate travel at this time. Unvaccinated travelers and residents returning from any U.S. state or territory beyond the immediate region should self-quarantine and/or get tested. You no longer need to quarantine or get tested before/after domestic travel if you are fully vaccinated or have clinically recovered from COVID-19 in the past three months.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210510094348/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/travel-and-transportation/are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: There are narrow protections for New Jersey workers, such as Work First New Jersey (WFNJ), which includes Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) and General Assistance (GA), which provides monthly cash. There are also unemployment benefits and emergency paid sick/childcare leave available for application.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518065609/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/assistance-and-benefits/what-types-of-benefits-or-assistance-are-available-to-me-during-the-coronavirus-outbreak
notes_E2: New Jerseyans are protected from eviction, and if affected by COVID-19, residents can apply to request mortgage payment forbearance for up to 90 days.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518065609/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/assistance-and-benefits/what-types-of-benefits-or-assistance-are-available-to-me-during-the-coronavirus-outbreak
notes_H1: Comprehensive public info available.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518064913/https://covid19.nj.gov/
notes_H2: Testing is available to everyone in New Jersey    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518065920/https://covid19.nj.gov/pages/testing
notes_H3: Comprehensive contact tracing in place    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518070027/https://covid19.nj.gov/pages/testandtrace     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516203924/https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/infectious-disease/epi/airborne/coronavirus/contact-tracing.shtml
notes_H6: All vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals must contine to wear face coverings in indoor spaces open to the public and in indoor commercial spaces closed to the public. Masks are no longer required in outdoor settings, though those who are unvaccinated should continue to exercise caution.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518070402/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/slowing-the-spread/should-i-wear-a-mask-to-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19
notes_H7: Everyone 12 or older who lives, works, or studies in New Jersey is now eligible for a COVID-19 vaccine    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518070548/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/slowing-the-spread/who-is-eligible-for-a-covid-19-vaccine-in-new-jersey

name: New Mexico
notes_C1: Although individual schools may close due to local outbreaks, schools are in general open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515184954/https://apnews.com/article/las-vegas-new-mexico-coronavirus-pandemic-santa-fe-6585ce5f47bbe2f801b29f0ec2eb6a2d
notes_C2: One county, "Chaves", is in the "yellow" tier, the second-highest level; none remain in the "red" tier. Businesses have capacity restrictions, with bars and clubs closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185138/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185134/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/public-dashboard.html
notes_C3: One county, "Chaves", is in the "yellow" tier, the second-highest level; none remain in the "red" tier. Outdoor events are permitted, but not indoor ones.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185138/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185134/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/public-dashboard.html
notes_C4: One county, "Chaves", is in the "yellow" tier, the second-highest level; none remain in the "red" tier. Gatherings of up to 10 people are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185138/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185134/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/public-dashboard.html
notes_C5: All transit operators in the state appear to have resumed service. A few individual bus routes and stops have been suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185330/https://www.riometro.org/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=237
notes_C6: Citizens are advised to stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185329/https://cv.nmhealth.org/covid-safe-practices/
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: Eviction moratorium extended through June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185808/https://www.reuters.com/world/us/federal-court-vacates-us-eviction-moratorium-2021-05-05/
notes_H1: Public campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185138/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_H2: Testing is widely available without restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185924/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/directory.html
notes_H3: No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515190025/https://cvmodeling.nmhealth.org/public-health-gating-criteria-for-reopening-nm/contact-tracing-and-isolation-capacity/
notes_H6: Regardless of case level, all parts of the state require mask-wearing in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515185138/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_H7: All residents over 16 are now eligible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515190220/https://cv.nmhealth.org/covid-vaccine/

name: Nevada
notes_C1: All schools appear to have reopened, with some distancing measures in effect.
notes_C2: Business closings have transitioned to local authority decisions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515204416/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/5.3.21-Local-Control.pdf

This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments. See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: Evictions restrictions continue.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423140840/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/3.31-Evictions-directive-signed.pdf
notes_H1: State-wide coordinated public campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210513231412/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/current-status-mitigation-measures/
notes_H2: Broad testing policy remains in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210508184228/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/find-covid-19-testing-in-nevada/
notes_H3: Limited contact tracing program involving the COVID Trace app continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210508184300/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/covidtrace/
notes_H6: Facial coverings are still required in all public spaces except for vaccinated people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515210309/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2021/may/13/nevada-drops-mask-mandate-for-vaccinated-people/
notes_H7: On April 5th, the vaccine appointments were made available to all individuals 16 and older in Nevada. Coded as a 5 due to universal availability.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210515210428/https://www.immunizenevada.org/county-specific-covid-19-vaccine-sites

name: New York
notes_C1: Theoretically, schools are open for in person learning through the high school level; some universities continue with all virtual instruction with hopes of reopening fully in the fall (many for vaccinated students only).    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145446/https://nyunews.com/news/2021/03/08/university-plans-return-to-in-person-instruction/    https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145409/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/07/nyregion/coronavirus-nyc-public-schools.html
notes_C2: "Effective May 19, most business capacities—which are currently based upon percentage of maximum occupancy—will be removed in New York and New Jersey. Businesses will only be limited by the space available for patrons or parties of patrons to maintain the required social distance of 6 feet." --NY state website. Capacity limits were raised for hair salons, barber shops, and other personal care services to 75% on 7 May.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516143452/https://forward.ny.gov/reopening-reference-guide
notes_C3: Only recommended to cancel public events in certain settings.
notes_C4: According to the NY state government website, many changes will be implemented on May 19:     "The outdoor non-residential social gathering limit will increase from 200 to 500 people on May 10.    The indoor non-residential social gathering limit will increase from 100 to 250 people on May 19.    The outdoor residential gathering limit of 25 people is removed as of May 19, reverting to the social gathering limit of 500 people with space for appropriate social distancing.    The indoor residential gathering limit will increase from 10 to 50 people on May 19."    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516143452/https://forward.ny.gov/reopening-reference-guide
notes_C5: State measures for reopening public transport are in place; no substantial reductions in service due to COVID. NYC subway will resume full 24-hour service on 17 May.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516143230/https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/PublicTransportationSummaryGuidance.pdf    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516143452/https://forward.ny.gov/reopening-reference-guide
notes_C6: Staying at home is only recommended for symptomatic individuals/travelers.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516142847/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C7: "Quarantine, consistent with the CDC recommendations, is still recommended for all travelers who are not fully vaccinated or have not recovered from laboratory confirmed COVID-19 during the previous 3 months."    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516142847/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Employees who must isolate due to COVID can get support from a combination of NYS Paid Family Leave and disability benefits.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516144703/https://paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/if-you-are-quarantined-yourself
notes_E2: The NY AG's temporary suspension of the collection of medical and student debt is in effect until 31 May 2021.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516144601/https://ag.ny.gov/covid-19-debt-suspension-application
notes_H1: No change.
notes_H2: No change.
notes_H3: No change.
notes_H6: The NY state government website says that New Yorkers should continue to mask and social distance while the vaccination program is underway.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516144007/https://covid19vaccine.health.ny.gov/
notes_H7: According to the NY government website, "All individuals 12 years of age and older that reside in the United States are eligible to receive the vaccine," after Pfizer was authorized in the US for youth 12 and up.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516144007/https://covid19vaccine.health.ny.gov/

name: Ohio
notes_C1: As of May 12, one school district in Ohio continues to operate fully remotely, with 78 others having hybrid learning and the remaining 530 being fully in-person: http://web.archive.org/web/20210516163959/https://77436.global.siteimproveanalytics.io/image.aspx?url=http%3A%2F%2Feducation.ohio.gov%2FTopics%2FReset-and-Restart&title=Reset%20and%20Restart%20%7C%20Ohio%20Department%20of%20Education&res=1600x1000&accountid=77436&rt=2481&prev=1cd6f098-ae71-0d8a-ecef-0c2d406a033a&luid=610aef45-06c1-211a-dd38-7d0fe0dd7b4d&rnd=61162
notes_C2: On May 12, Gov. DeWine announced that current Health Orders would remain until 02 June: http://web.archive.org/web/20210516172209/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use/covid-19-update-05-12-21.    No additional changes regarding workplace closures were found in state press releases or Internet search and Ohio continues to recommend working from home and taking precautions in the workplace: http://web.archive.org/web/20210516172445/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use
notes_C3: On May 12, Gov. DeWine announced that current Health Orders would remain in place until 02 June: http://web.archive.org/web/20210516172209/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use/covid-19-update-05-12-21. notes_C4: On May 12, Gov. DeWine announced that current Health Orders would remain in place until 02 June: http://web.archive.org/web/20210516172209/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use/covid-19-update-05-12-21. notes_C5: As of 16 May, no public transit closures have been identified in Ohio via DoT website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210516175451/https://www.transportation.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/odot/about-us/news/all-news and Internet search.    Transit systems in major cities remain open:  GoMetro (Cincinnati): http://web.archive.org/web/20210516175824/https://www.go-metro.com/about-metro/about2/Coronavirus-Info  COTA (Columbus): http://web.archive.org/web/20210516175840/https://www.cota.com/coronavirus/
notes_C6: As of 16 May, no changes to policies regarding stay at home requirements were found in state press releases or Internet searches.    Link to Ohio state COVID-19 press releases:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210516172445/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use
notes_C7: As of 16 May, Ohio maintains its recommendations against internal travel - especially for the unvaccinated: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517034938/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/families-and-individuals/COVID-19-Travel-Advisory/COVID-19-Travel-Advisory
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of 16 May, Ohio has not made any changes to their Pandemic Unemployment Assistance Program: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517041455/https://unemploymenthelp.ohio.gov/expandedeligibilityFAQ/
notes_E2: As of 16 May, Ohio has not made any changes to its larger policies on debt/contract relief and doesn't freeze financial obligations on a large scale. They continue to offer homeowners various application-based assistance: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517042057/https://businesshelp.ohio.gov/home-relief-grant.html    Link to state COVID financial assistance programs page:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517042305/https://dodd.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/dodd/about-us/communication/news/news-covid-19-financial-assistance-programs
notes_H1: As of 17 May, Ohio continues to provide COVID-19 updates across different media.     Link to state Coronavirus website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517155322/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/home    Links to relevant Twitter pages:  Dept. of Health: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517155008/https://twitter.com/OHdeptofhealth  Gov. Mike DeWine: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517155358/https://twitter.com/GovMikeDeWine
notes_H2: As of 17 May, Ohio maintains its policy of having tests available to the general public: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517155953/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/general-resources/get-tested-for-covid-19    Link to list of testing centers: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517160040/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/dashboards/other-resources/testing-ch-centers
notes_H3: As of 17 May, no changes to Ohio's contract tracing policies per websites of state government and large municipalities - the state continues to offer the service in all cases.    Link to state government page: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517160547/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/responsible-restart-ohio/contact-tracing/contact-tracing  Link to Cincinnati government page: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517160903/https://www.cincinnati-oh.gov/health/covid-19/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: On 14 May, Gov. DeWine announced forthcoming orders to lift mask mandates for vaccinated individuals (which have yet to take effect as of 17 May) and the intention to lift the mandate generally on 02 June, with no policy changes to be made in the interim: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517162349/https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2021/05/14/ohio-change-mask-mandate-health-orders-cdc-guidance/5095879001/    Link to Ohio Public Health Orders site on 17 May: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517162630/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/public-health-orders
notes_H7: As of 17 May, there have been no further changes to Ohio's vaccine distribution - the Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines remain universally available to adults: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517163745/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/covid-19-vaccination-program/covid-19-vaccination-program

name: Oklahoma
notes_C1: Since April 5, 2021, all students in grades PK-12th can return to Campus for in-person learning 4 days a week, Tuesday - Friday. Mondays will remain a remote learning day for all students. Children in Workplace Program will end as students return. OKCPS Curbside Meal Service will remain in place at all school sites on Mondays only.    Broken Arrow Public Schools is currently on YELLOW PHASE meaning Social distancing practiced as much as possible, Large group activities-school-wide assemblies may be allowed with students and teacher only, large group activities must be limited so social distancing may be practiced, mandatory masks for grades 3-5.    University of Oklahoma: The Norman campus is currently in Phase III of its Return Plan meaning mandatory COVID-19 screening and reporting is mandatory for Faculty, Staff, Students, and Visitors    OKCPS Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517232525/https://www.okcps.org/domain/1846    Broken Arrow Public Schools Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517232048/https://www.baschools.org/    University of Oklahoma Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517232839/https://www.ou.edu/together    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517233033/https://www.ou.edu/together/response
notes_C2: Businesses and organizations are required to follow the Open Up & Recover Safely Plan. Businesses are allowed to remain open but Employees and visitors must follow sanitation, hygiene and social distancing guidelines.     Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510223359/https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf    https://archive.ph/9c6rP
notes_C3: Tulsa city limits follow the State of Oklahoma’s OURS Plan. Public events are allowed but people are encouraged to follow sanitations and disinfecting guidelines, hygiene and social distancing considerations.     Link:   https://archive.ph/9c6rP    https://web.archive.org/web/20210203070511/https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Entertainment-and-Sporting-Venue-Guidance.pdf
notes_C4: On March 12, 2021 Gov. Kevin Stitt announced he will issue a new executive order eliminating limits on public gatherings and attendance limits at indoor sporting events. No further large changes were made since then. No new executive order was found.     Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503031339if_/https://www.oklahoman.com/story/news/2021/03/11/oklahoma-gov-kevin-stitt-undo-remaining-covid-19-restrictions/6947773002/
notes_C5: No new changes. EMBARK capacity limits are as follows: 12-person capacity for 30’ buses, 14-person capacity for 35’ buses, 16-person capacity for 40’ buses, 4 ambulatory and 1 wheelchair on Plus Paratransit vehicles, 16-person capacity for OKC streetcar. Employees and passengers will still be required to wear a mask while on transit vehicles and EMBARK facilities.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518035225/https://embarkok.com/connect/blog/2020/03/staying-healthy/
notes_C6: As of May 11, 2021, the COVID-19 alert system report shows that many counties are now yellow (1.43 to 14.29 cases per 100 000) , 25 are green (less than 1.43 cases per 100 000) and 1 remain orange (more than 14.29 cases per 100 000). General guidelines for individuals include staying home if feeling sick. General guidelines for high-risk individuals include using appropriate precautions and avoiding high-risk areas for any travel.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518041417/https://oklahoma.gov/content/dam/ok/en/covid19/documents/alert-system/risk-level-trends/County%20Risk%20Levels%2020210511.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518041532/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/covid-19-alert-system.html
notes_C7: The “Safer in Oklahoma” policy is still running. “Individuals entering the State of Oklahoma from an area with substantial community spread, will wear a face covering in all public spaces and limit participating indoor gatherings for 10-14 days in accordance with CDC guidelines.” Public health officials recommend staying at home as much as possible and practice social distancing after a trip.     Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518041720/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/resources-recommendations/travel.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: “Today Governor Kevin Stitt and Oklahoma Employment Security Commission Executive Director Shelley Zumwalt announced a new Return to Work Incentive for Oklahomans who are on unemployment. The first 20,000 Oklahomans currently receiving unemployment benefits who return to the workforce will receive a $1,200 incentive using funds from the American Rescue Plan.”  - Executive Order 2021-15     Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518042807/https://www.governor.ok.gov/articles/press_releases/governor-kevin-stitt--oesc-executive-director-zumw    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043018/https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/2003.pdf
notes_E2: No changes. "The moratorium that was scheduled to expire on March 31, 2021 is now extended through June 30, 2021."     Link: https://archive.vn/qziss
notes_H1: The Oklahoma Department of Health continues to encourage residents to get vaccinated through their Twitter.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043438/https://twitter.com/healthyoklahoma?lang=es
notes_H2: The OCCHD will schedule appointments for anyone wanting to be tested. Testing sites can be found online.     Tulsa Health Department conducts specimen collection for testing by appointment only.     Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210511014223/https://www.occhd.org/okctestsites    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043924/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/testing-sites.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518044019/https://www.tulsa-health.org/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/testing
notes_H3: “Contact tracing for COVID-19 typically involves Interviewing people with COVID-19 to identify everyone they had close contact with during the time they may have been infectious”. There are approximately 700 trained contact tracers currently working active cases in Oklahoma.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518044320/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/resources-recommendations/contact-tracing-0.html
notes_H6: Masks mandate is nolonger in effect, however any business or venue may still choose to require masks at their establishment. Patrons who refuse to wear a mask in such an establishment will be subject to trespassing violations. Masks are still required in Tulsa International Airport.     The City of Tulsa’s face mask ordinance expired on April 30th. However, face masks are required on all Tulsa Transit vehicles.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518044658/https://www.cityoftulsa.org/masks    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518044921/https://www.tulsaairports.com/news/covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518034412/http://tulsatransit.org/2021/04/face-mask-required/
notes_H7: Vaccine appointments are available for all adults aged 16 and older, living in any state. Oklahoma residency is no longer required.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518045050/https://vaccinate.oklahoma.gov/en-US/

name: Oregon
notes_C1: Face covering and social distancing requirements in schools will remain in place until at least the end of the academic year, according to Governor Brown. The University of Oregon and Western Oregon University are planning to require students to be vaccinated for the autumn term.  Governor Brown's Statement: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514094820/https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FFbhH9q0Lf-b0TQvOYAgYLpfeKP3crJ-/view // https://web.archive.org/web/20210514094927/https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TTifiyJTj5sCfjkrP_qJmyKstAkkO8vT/view  KTVZ on University vaccination requirements: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514095150/https://ktvz.com/news/coronavirus/2021/05/10/western-oregon-university-to-require-covid-19-vaccinations-for-students-staff-in-fall/  University of Oregon Statment: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514095310/https://president.uoregon.edu/covid-19-vaccine-requirement
notes_C2: As of 14th May 2021, the 'one-week shutdown' of the 15 counties moved to the extreme risk level has ended, and 24 of Oregon's 36 counties are now at high risk, 4 at moderate and 8 at lower. On May 11th Governor Brown announced her plan for the risk levels system to be removed once 70% or Oregonians have recieved at least one vaccine, speculated (dubiously, in my opinion) to be the threshold for herd immunity. Businesses and employers may soon be given the option to waive mask and social distancing requirements for the fully-vaccinated, in line with CDC guidance.  At high risk level, home working, outdoor dining and business closure are only recommended, rather than required, though capacity limits are still in place in most venues    Governor Brown's Statements: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514094820/https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FFbhH9q0Lf-b0TQvOYAgYLpfeKP3crJ-/view // https://web.archive.org/web/20210514094927/https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TTifiyJTj5sCfjkrP_qJmyKstAkkO8vT/view // https://web.archive.org/web/20210514101734/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54693  Governor Brown on NPR (radio broadcast): https://web.archive.org/web/20210514101317/https://www.npr.org/2021/05/12/996286541/gov-kate-brown-on-oregons-covid-19-spike?t=1620984788871  OPB on the reopening plan: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514101422/https://www.opb.org/article/2021/05/11/oregon-covid-19-vaccine-gov-kate-brown-restrictions-coronavirus-cases/ // https://web.archive.org/web/20210514101558/https://www.opb.org/article/2021/05/13/oregon-covid-19-vaccine-mask-mandate/  Current county risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514101912/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  Current county guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514102032/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx
notes_C3: At 'high' risk level, capacity restrictions (15% outdoors and 10% indoors, 25% for faith insitutions, funeral homes and eating and drinking establishments) and an 11PM curfew are in place for indoor and outdoor venues. At the high risk level, gatherings are limited to 6 people indoors and 8 outdoors. At low risk level the limits are 10 and 12 respectively, being 8 and 10 at moderate risk level.    As of 14th May 2021, the 'one-week shutdown' of the 15 counties moved to the extreme risk level has ended, and 24 of Oregon's 36 counties are now at high risk, 4 at moderate and 8 at lower. On May 11th Governor Brown announced her plan for the risk levels system to be removed once 70% or Oregonians have recieved at least one vaccine, speculated (dubiously, in my opinion) to be the threshold for herd immunity. Businesses and employers may soon be given the option to waive mask and social distancing requirements for the fully-vaccinated, in line with CDC guidance. notes_C4: At the high risk level, gatherings are limited to 6 people indoors and 8 outdoors. At low risk level the limits are 10 and 12 respectively, being 8 and 10 at moderate risk level. On May 11th Governor Brown announced her plan for the risk levels system to be removed once 70% or Oregonians have recieved at least one vaccine, speculated (dubiously, in my opinion) to be the threshold for herd immunity. notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The following policy remains in effect:  PUA provides unemployment benefits to workers who have never before been eligible for benefits. To qualify, you must be:  Out of work due to COVID-19, and  Not eligible for any other unemployment benefits. This includes:  Self-employed people  Independent contractors  Some gig workers (gig workers whose employers are not required to pay payroll taxes on their wages)  Employees whose wages are not reported for unemployment insurance, like some agricultural workers  Employees who have not earned enough wages or worked enough hours for regular unemployment benefits  Employees who ran out of regular unemployment benefits, and are not eligible for another extension  People who were going to start work but could not, due to a COVID-19 situation  The minimum PUA benefit is $205 per week. You will get at least that much if you are eligible. The maximum is $648 per week. Your weekly benefit amount is 1.25 percent of your earnings over the last 12 months. It is net earnings (earnings minus expenses) for self-employed workers, but gross earnings (total earnings) for other workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331213858/https://unemployment.oregon.gov/frequently-asked-questions#faqTopic-2008
notes_E2: No new announcements
