name: Pennsylvania
notes_C1: According to the Philadelphia Inquirer, "Schools also no longer need to report their coronavirus prevention measures to the state, but the updates don’t prevent municipalities?and school districts?from?implementing?stricter mitigation?efforts, says the Department of Health." Some school districts have their own mitigation measures in place.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516151756/https://www.inquirer.com/philly-tips/philadelphia-reopening-guide-20210515.html
notes_C2: "Effective May 17, 2021, maximum capacity limits for events and gatherings will be increased to 50% for indoor and 75% for outdoor." All COVID mitigation measures to be lifted by 31 May. All in-person businesses may operate at 75% occupancy  Indoor dining at restaurants open at 50% (75% for self-certified restaurants)    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_C3: On 17 May, maximum capacity limits for events will be increased to 50% indoor and 75% outdoor. Most events can take place in some capacity.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_C4: Gathering limits will be updated 17 May to increase max capacity limits.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_C5: No measures observed. A public transport in PA is offering free rides to vaccination appointments for seniors: "The rides will be courtesy of regional public transportation provider rabbittransit, in partnership with local Area Agency on Aging offices across several counties in the south-central Pennsylvania region"    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516151236/https://www.masstransitmag.com/safety-security/news/21214047/pa-free-transportation-to-get-covid19-vaccines-is-being-offered-through-area-agencies-for-seniors
notes_C6: No measures observed; all COVID mitigation measures will be lifted 31 May.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Narrow unemployment compensation on the state level is available, with guidance on the state website for eligibility.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516150635/https://www.uc.pa.gov/COVID-19/Pages/Services-for-PA-COVID19.aspx
notes_E2: PA does not have its own, state-specific eviction moratorium; renters have been relying on federal protections.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516150517/https://www.inquirer.com/real-estate/housing/eviction-moratorium-cdc-ruling-philadelphia-pa-nj-20210506.html
notes_H1: No change.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_H2: No change.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_H3: No change.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_H6: According to the PA government website, the masking order in public will be lifted when 70% of Pennsylvania adults are fully vaccinated.    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_H7: According to the PA government website, "Pennsylvanians age 12 and over are now eligible for the COVID vaccine. Adolescents ages 12-15 can receive the Pfizer vaccine."    Source: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20210516145949/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/

name: Rhode Island
notes_C1: On 14 May 2021 in EO 21-50, Governor Daniel McKee set out further regulations for in-person learning at institutes of higher education in Rhode Island.    - IHEs shall conduct either initial surveillance testing for COVID-19 for all students prior to the start of in-person learning or shall require each student to present a negative COVID-19 test taken within 72 hours of arriving on campus and shall conduct continued surveillance testing in accordance with regulations promulgated by RIDOH. These surveillance testing requirements do not apply to students participating in remote learning only.  -  Residential IHEs are delegated with the authority to and shall conduct all case identification interviews for students, faculty, and staff who test positive for COVID-19 through the institution's surveillance testing. This should also be done for close contacts.  - Residential IHEs shall provide isolation housing to all undergraduate students who test positive for COVID-19 and shall provide quarantine housing to all undergraduate students identified as close contacts of those who test positive.  - IHEs must have or enact codes of student conduct that include the potential for suspension and/or expulsion for non-compliance with all institutionally enacted rules regarding COVID-19.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517162754/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-50.pdf
notes_C2: As of 17 May 2021, EO 21-46 (Amended and Restated Protecting Your Household Order) remains in effect.    The following workplace restrictions are in place:    - Restaurants may operate indoor dining in addition to outdoor dining (subject to applicable municipal approval), pick-up, delivery, and drive-through operations  - People should work remotely if possible.   - Nightclubs must remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161433/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf
notes_C3: As of 17 May 2021, EO 21-46 (Amended and Restated Protecting Your Household Order) remains in effect.     The following public event restrictions are in place:    - Subject to compliance with applicable requirements such as physical distancing and masking, venues of assembly, including convention centers, concert halls, performance venues, spectator sporting event venues and theaters may operate up to 80% of regular venue capacity with a cap of 500 people indoors.  - Religious and faith-based organizations may conduct in-person activities up to 80% percent of worship space capacity  - All indoor sporting facilities, such as indoor ice rinks and basketball courts, may operate up to 80% of facility capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161433/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf
notes_C4: As of 17 May 2021, EO 21-46 (Amended and Restated Protecting Your Household Order) remains in effect.     The following gathering restrictions are in place:    - Indoor public and private social gatherings are limited to 25 people  - Outdoor public and private social gatherings are limited to 75 people    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161433/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf
notes_C5: As of 17 May 2021, no evidence has been found for amendments to public transportation services in Rhode Island. Executive orders, press releases and news articles have been searched.    Rhode Island Public Transit Authority states that face masks are required to be worn at all times and social distancing should be observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517162044/https://www.ripta.com/covid-19/
notes_C6: As of 17 May, EO 21-46 (Amended and Restated Protecting Your Household Order) remains in effect.     Working from home is encouraged as an effective arrangement to reduce work-related spread among employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161433/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf
notes_C7: As of 17 May 2021, EO 21-46 (Amended and Restated Protecting Your Household Order) remains in effect.    - Any person coming to Rhode Island for a non-work-related purpose from locations with a high community spread rate as set forth on a list maintained by RIDOH at https://covid.ri.gov/ must immediately self-quarantine for 10 days. Exemptions apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161433/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-46.pdf
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of 17 May 2021, there has been no change identified for income support.     Those who have been laid off due to the pandemic may be eligible for the state's unemployment insurance. If individuals are self-employed or a contract worker, they must apply for Pandemic Unemployment Assistance.    It remains unclear whether this support provides <50% or >50% of the lost income. Coding as 1F, however this may not reflect the situation on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161240/https://dlt.ri.gov/ui/faq/
notes_E2: As of 17 May 2021, the winter moratorium on utilities remains in effect.     This moratorium will expire on 25 June 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161103/https://www.providenceri.gov/pema/covid-19-housing-resource-guide/
notes_H1: As of 17 May 2021, Rhode Island's Department of Health continues to provide information pertaining to the COVID-19 response within the state via the RIDOH COVID-19 website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517160924/https://covid.ri.gov/
notes_H2: As of 17 May 2021, there is no detected change in Rhode Island's testing policy.    Testing is currently widely available, regardless of whether individuals are symptomatic or asymptomatic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517160755/https://covid.ri.gov/testing
notes_H3: As of 17 May 2021, no evidence has been identified to suggest a deviation away from comprehensive contact tracing in Rhode Island. Executive orders, press releases and news articles have been searched.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517160659/https://covid.ri.gov/covid-19-prevention/contact-tracing
notes_H6: As of 17 May 2021, EO 21-47 remains in effect.    Any person whether indoors or outdoors, shall be required to wear a mask or cloth face covering. Masks are not required outdoors when at least three feet away from others.    EO 21-47:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517160428/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-47.pdf
notes_H7: As of 17 May 2021, all individuals age 16 and above remain eligible for vaccination in Rhode Island. The Moderna, Pfizer and J&J vaccines are being administered to these age groups. Additionally, individuals age 12 and above are eligible for the Pfizer vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517160002/https://covid.ri.gov/vaccination/covid-19-vaccine-faqs

name: South Carolina
notes_C1: Schools recommended to follow CDC guidelines surrounding implementation of strategies that align with local level of transmission https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233817/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/resources-community-covid-19/schools-childcare-centers-covid-19
notes_C2: As of May 10th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210506120134/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509063451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: Enacted 08 March 2021, Executive Order No. 2021-13 extends Executive Order No. 2021-12 (enacted 05 March 2021) for 15 days, until 22 March 2021. Executive Order No. 2021-12 modifies and renews emergency measures for COVID-19.    Executive Order No. 2021-12 recommends that businesses, facilities, events, and other mass gatherings do not exceed 250 people or 50% of a facility's occupancy limit, whichever comes first (see Section 4 Paragraph B).  This is a change from Executive Order No. 2020-73, which prohibited gatherings of this size.     According to Executive Order No. 2021-12, a gathering does not include military, healthcare, public safety, emergency response, or the United States CISA operations. It also does not include schools and higher education institutions or religious activities or services and the facilities in which they occur (see Section 4 Paragraph C).     Residents of South Carolina partaking in gatherings are still encouraged to practice social distancing (in accordance with the CDC, DHEC, etc).    Link to Executive Order No. 2021-13 (searchable text):  https://archive.ph/yP0G4  Link to Executive Order No. 2021-12 (searchable text):  https://archive.vn/AaAlg
notes_C4: The latest updated Executive Order from the Governor of the state includes no mention of restrictions on gatherings (previous orders included specific passaged on emergency restrictions on gatherings).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210421112834/https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Images/2021-04-07%20FINAL%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-18%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf
notes_C5: Enacted 08 March 2021, Executive Order No. 2021-13 extends Executive Order No. 2021-12 (enacted 05 March 2021) for 15 days, until 22 March 2021. Executive Order No. 2021-12 modifies and renews emergency measures for COVID-19.    There are no statewide restrictions on public transportation.     Link to Executive Order No. 2021-13 (searchable text):  https://archive.ph/yP0G4  Link to Executive Order No. 2021-12 (searchable text):  https://archive.vn/AaAlg
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: On May 7th "the U.S. Department of the Treasury, in coordination with the White House American Rescue Plan Implementation Team and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced the allocation of an additional $21.6 billion under the American Rescue Plan for Emergency Rental Assistance, which will help prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507202118/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0168
notes_H1: The state department of health continues to urge people to wear masks and exercise caution with social distancing measures   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502234759/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/frequently-asked-questions-covid-19
notes_H2: Testing locations are available throughout the state with many free options through the state department of health  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502234645/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-testing-locations
notes_H3: "South Carolinians are asking what they can to do stop the spread of COVID-19. Our response – answer the call. If you receive a call from 803-529-1551, please answer. This is a call from a contact monitor and answering will keep your loved ones and community safe through a process called contact tracing. All information collected by DHEC’s trained contact tracers is voluntary, confidential and over the phone."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210421113409/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-contact-tracing
notes_H6: On May 16th, the CDC update their guidelines stating:   "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic.  Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517020830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Janssen

Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412212113/https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/economic-recovery/close-contact-business-guidelines.html
notes_H6: As of May 9th, Nashville and Davidson county still enforced their indoor public mask mandate despite governor’s executive order requiring health departments across Tennessee to rescind their mask mandate by May 30th.     News update: http://web.archive.org/web/20210509053213/https://www.murfreesboropost.com/surrounding-counties-ended-mask-mandates-weeks-ago-nashville-wont-budge/article_3a8bfd0b-935a-512c-95d5-dc3f78b3c436.html    EO 80: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502110444/https://www.tn.gov/governor/news/2021/4/27/gov--lee-pushes-reopening--focus-on-economic-recovery.html   Nashville: http://web.archive.org/web/20210509053459/https://www.wsmv.com/news/davidson_county/metro-to-drop-all-covid-19-restrictions-except-mask-mandate-on-may-14/article_c9a766f8-a6eb-11eb-a9f2-ebab11eb2af3.html   Davidson County: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502114340/https://twitter.com/NashvilleHealth/status/1387037055545483265
notes_H7: A, B, C: As of May 9th, all residents aged 16 or above were eligible to receive Covid-19 vaccine for free. Residents could choose between getting Pfizer, Moderna, or Johnson & Johnson.     Eligibility: http://web.archive.org/web/20210509053750/https://covid19.tn.gov/covid-19-vaccines/availability/   Vaccines: http://web.archive.org/web/20210509054059/https://covid19.tn.gov/covid-19-vaccines/   FAQs: http://web.archive.org/web/20210509054344/https://covid19.tn.gov/covid-19-vaccines/vaccine-faqs/

name: Texas
notes_C1: Indicator moved to 1T as no levels are required to be or are effectively closed in any region of the state.     As of May 10th, essentially all Texas grade schools are offering in-person courses following a statewide mandate. Public schools must offer an in person option in order to "not lose state funding due to declines in enrollment. School districts can require individual students who are falling behind academically to return to in-person classes."    While universities are generally enforcing precautionary COVID-19 policies, both the University of Texas at Austin and Texas A&M University (the two largest in the state) are offering at least some regular programming in person.     Sources:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511015610/https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-schools-reopening/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511015539/https://coronavirus.utexas.edu/campus-announcements    https://archive.vn/7VCAE
notes_C2: Recoded to 1G because no sectors are required to closed, although COVID mitigation policies are still in effect.     As of May 10th, no business sectors are required to close. For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect.  In all counties without high hospitalization, there are no COVID-19 related operation limits for any business or establishments (e.g., gyms, salons, restaurants, public and private schools, childcare services). Businesses can now operate at 100% occupancy, unless county judges use COVID related mitigation strategies-limited to no less than a 50% total occupancy. As of May 10th, no regions are above the threshold for high hospitalization.     The Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Guidelines require  at least 6 feet between groups of 10 or fewer and face coverings in establishments and businesses.       Sources:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510032836/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509001244/https://www.dshs.texas.gov/GA34/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511020555/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_C3: As of May 11, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Travis county, which includes Austin. These will expire May 18, 2021. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people or less. However, the City of Austin has released information on holding public events safely. Thus, indicators is placed at 1T.     For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect. There are no evident executive state orders on the limit or restriction of public events.     Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222519/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules     https://web.archive.org/web/20210512040001/http://austintexas.gov/news/city-austin-launches-plan-bring-events-back-safely    https://web.archive.org/web/20210416183108/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Health-Authority-Rules-April-13-2021.pdf
notes_C4: As of May 11, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Travis county, which includes Austin. These will expire May 18, 2021. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people or fewer.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512040151/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_C5: As of May 11th, there are still no major public transit closures statewide.
notes_C6: As of May 11th, 2021, Travis County, which includes Austin, remains in stage three, where guidelines state that unvaccinated or partially vaccinated people at high risk (e.g., 65+, high blood pressure, diabetes) are encouraged to avoid non-essential dining and shopping but there is no requirement. There are no statewide recommendations or requirements to stay home.     Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512040934/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/covid-19-risk-based-guidelines
notes_C7: As of May 4th, 2021 Austin and Travis county remain in stage 3. Guidelines now only advise unvaccinated or partially vaccinated people at high risk (e.g., 65+, high blood pressure, diabetes) to avoid non essential travel, but this is not a legal requirement. There are no further recommendations or restrictions statewide. As a result, coding changed to a 1T.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512040934/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/covid-19-risk-based-guidelines
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of May 3, 2021, the Texas Rent Relief Program continues (Launched Feb.15, 2021). The program provides monetary assistance to households in paying rent or utilities, Qualifying households can make no more than 80% of an area’s median income. Priority will be given to households making less than 50% of an areas median income or household members unemployed for at least 90 days.  Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222919/https://texasrentrelief.com/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209191920/https://www.statesman.com/story/news/politics/state/2021/02/09/texas-gov-greg-abbott-rent-relief-program-launches-covid-pandemic/4449250001/
notes_E2: As of May 3, 2021 the Texas Eviction Diversion Program remains in effect.       Link to the TEDP:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426163402/https://www.tdhca.state.tx.us/TEDP.htm     https://web.archive.org/web/20210217203258/https://www.txcourts.gov/media/1451765/219015.pdf
notes_H1: As of May 3, 2021, up to date information on covid is still provided through social media (e.g., twitter) and the Texas government website.    Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223102/https://www.texas.gov/covid19/     https://archive.vn/cYfUc
notes_H2: As of May 3, 2021, public screening and antibody collection sites are still available statewide- in person and at drive through locations. People with symptoms are encouraged to get tested, but symptoms are not required for a test.    General Testing Information Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503224155/https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/testing.aspx     Testing Location Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025832/https://tdem.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=1e91fb79fa44417898738e5bff31a3d8%2F
notes_H3: As of May 3, 2021 contact tracing efforts continue in Texas but participation in efforts is voluntary. Texas currently has 3192 tracers.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223949/https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/tracing.aspx     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503212531/https://testandtrace.com/state-data/
notes_H6: As of May 3, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Face coverings in establishments, businesses, and in public areas are required. Austin has clearance to enforce its own mandate, given court ruling (March 26 2021). As a result, coding remains 3T.    On a state level, Executive Order GA34 remains in effect.  All mask mandates have been removed. While individuals are no longer required by law to wear face coverings, individuals are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings when it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household (unvaccinated status).    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419212756/https://www.kxan.com/news/local/austin/austin-public-health-provides-update-on-vaccine-guidance-extends-health-rules-through-may-18/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222519/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules    https://web.archive.org/web/20210416183108/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Health-Authority-Rules-April-13-2021.pdf
notes_H7: As of May 3, 2021 Texas eligibility for COVID-19 vaccination remains open to individuals aged 16+.     Moderna vaccine is being used for individuals 18 and older, while the Pfizer vaccine is authorized for people 16 and older. The Texas Health commissioner is now asking that sites now resume use of the  Johnson & Johnson/Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, after US health officials ended their vaccine halt (Friday April 23, 2021).    Texas State Vaccination Requirement Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223729/https://dshs.texas.gov/coronavirus/immunize/vaccine.aspx     Texas DSHS/ News Vaccine Update:  https://archive.vn/cYfUc        Continuation of  J&J Vaccine:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426164412/https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/texas/articles/2021-04-24/texas-health-commissioner-says-j-j-vaccines-should-resume

name: Utah
notes_C1: Following multiple local school districts' movements to cancel in-school mask mandates, Governor Cox lifted the statewide K-12 masking requirement for the last week of school. The K-12 masking mandate is set to end on May 15th.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518033234/https://www.sltrib.com/news/2021/05/13/watch-live-gov-spencer/
notes_C2: As of May 9th, Grand County remains the only county in the high transmission tier.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210509134520/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C3: On May 4th, Utah lifted restrictions on gatherings and distancing. Masks are no longer required regardless of county spread levels. Mitigation measures are still recommended at gatherings statewide. Recoded to 1G to indicate lack of targeting.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518040319/https://www.abc4.com/coronavirus/utah-reaches-criteria-to-lift-covid-19-public-health-orders/    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210504011027/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C4: On May 4th, Utah lifted all restrictions on gatherings and distancing. Masks are no longer required regardless of county spread levels. Mitigation measures are still recommended at gatherings statewide.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518040319/https://www.abc4.com/coronavirus/utah-reaches-criteria-to-lift-covid-19-public-health-orders/    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210504011027/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C5: As of May 4th, no changes in this indicator.
notes_C6: As of May 4th, there are still no stay at home requirements.
notes_C7: As of May 10th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: On May 7th "the U.S. Department of the Treasury, in coordination with the White House American Rescue Plan Implementation Team and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced the allocation of an additional $21.6 billion under the American Rescue Plan for Emergency Rental Assistance, which will help prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507202118/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0168
notes_H1: As of May 2, there are no changes in this indicator. The state is maintaining a coordinated internet presence.
notes_H2: As of May 2, there are no changes in this indicator. The previous note is reproduced below:    "Testing available to those who are symptomatic and/or who made effective contact with someone who has COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424142640/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/"
notes_H3: As of May 2, contact tracing continues. However, the state contact tracing website states that "Some health departments are not able to do contact tracing right now and are focusing their limited and strained resources on case investigations. If you were exposed to someone who has COVID-19 you should quarantine for 14 days, even if the health department doesn’t contact you."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171856/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H6: Following multiple local school districts' movements to cancel in-school mask mandates, Governor Cox lifted the statewide K-12 masking requirement for the last week of school. The K-12 masking mandate is set to end on May 15th.     Masks are still required in certain public spaces by local mandate, and may be required by businesses. For instance, by mayoral order, masks are required in all municipal buildings in Salt Lake City.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518033234/https://www.sltrib.com/news/2021/05/13/watch-live-gov-spencer/    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043336/https://www.fox13now.com/news/coronavirus/local-coronavirus-news/mayor-signs-executive-order-requiring-masks-in-salt-lake-city-facilities
notes_H7: On May 13th, Utah began vaccinating minors aged 12-15. Children in this age group are only eligible to receive Pfizer vaccine. Moderna and J&J vaccines are being administered for those 18+.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514190438/https://www.abc4.com/coronavirus/walgreens-now-offering-pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-for-12-to-15-year-olds/

name: Virginia
notes_C1: No change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515020833/https://www.doe.virginia.gov/support/health_medical/office/covid-19-faq-reopening.shtml
notes_C2: No change in policy found.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516160058/https://www.virginia.gov/coronavirus/forwardvirginia/faq/?1
notes_C3: No change in policy found.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515005213/https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2021/april/headline-894593-en.html
notes_C4: Beginning on 15 May, the following changes went into effect:  “Social gatherings: The maximum number of individuals permitted in a social gathering will increase to 100 people for indoor settings and 250 people for outdoor settings. Social gatherings are currently limited to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.     Entertainment venues: Indoor entertainment and public amusement venues will be able to operate at 50 percent capacity or 1,000 people, up from 30 percent capacity or 500 people. Outdoor venues will be able to operate at 50 percent capacity—up from 30 percent—with no specific cap on the number of attendees.    Recreational sporting events: The number of spectators allowed at indoor recreational sporting events will increase from 100 to 250 spectators or 50 percent capacity, whichever is less. Outdoor recreational sporting events will increase from 500 to 1,000 people or 50 percent capacity, whichever is less.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515005213/https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2021/april/headline-894593-en.html
notes_C5: No change in policy found    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516164132/https://www.virginiadot.org/newsroom/covid-19/default.asp
notes_C6: No change in policy found    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516165449/https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2021/may/headline-895235-en.html

If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510073755/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: Not change in policy found. The Virginia Rent Relief Program is still in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511213556/https://www.dhcd.virginia.gov/rmrp
notes_H1: No change found. The Virginia Department of Health’s website continues to provide updated information, including a daily dashboard.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516184657/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/
notes_H2: No change detected.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516192847/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/covid-19-testing/
notes_H3: No change detected. Virginia continues to record daily numbers of cases, as well as conduct contact tracing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516195317/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/covid-19-data-insights/covid-19-contact-tracing/
notes_H6: On 14 May 2021, Virginia lifted the universal indoor mask mandate to align with new CDC guidance.    “The CDC guidelines state that fully-vaccinated individuals do not have to wear masks in most indoor settings, except on public transit, in health care facilities, and in congregate settings. Businesses retain the ability to require masks in their establishments. Employees who work in certain business sectors—including restaurants, retail, fitness, personal care, and entertainment—must continue to wear masks unless fully vaccinated, per CDC guidance. Those who are unvaccinated or not fully-vaccinated are strongly encouraged to wear masks in all settings.  The state of emergency in Virginia will remain in place at least through June 30 to provide flexibility for local government and support ongoing COVID-19 vaccination efforts. Governor Northam will take executive action to ensure individuals have the option to wear masks up to and after that date. Masks will continue to be required in K-12 public schools, given low rates of vaccination among children.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516165449/https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2021/may/headline-895235-en.html
notes_H7: As of 13 May 2021, all Virginia workers and residents 12 years and older are eligible for scheduling, vaccination, and general COVID inquiry services, according to the Virginia Department of Health. This reflects the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s expansion of the emergency use authorization for the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine to include adolescents 12 through 15 years of age.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210516200729/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/covid-19-faq/vaccination/

name: Vermont
notes_C1: As of May 11, 2021, there has been no change. Continuing to code as 2T - neither universities nor schools are completely open for in-person teaching. However, the state released further guidance on end of year school gatherings and graduations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518025501/https://education.vermont.gov/covid19
notes_C2: Effective May 1, 2021, the Vermont Forward plan continues with universal guidance in most business sectors, except as noted below in specialized guidance.    The following sectors will move to Universal Guidance but still retain specialized guidance:   •	7.1: Restaurants, Catering, Food Service, Social Clubs and Bars   •	9.1: Sports/Organized Sports Including Youth Leagues, Adult Leagues, Practices, Games, and Tournaments    The following sectors will retain specialized guidance and not move to Universal Guidance:  •	8.2: Overnight Summer Camps and Limited Residential Summer College Programming  •	11.1: College and University Campus Learning  •	12.1: Ski Resorts  •	Health Care  •	Education    No workplace closures have been listed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518023604/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations
notes_C3: As of May 14, 2021, Vermont is still limiting social gatherings and events based on whether one is fully vaccinated or not and the mandatory guidelines for businesses and organizations hosting events remain the same. The permission for all event venues; arts, culture, and entertainment venues; restaurants; bars; and clubs serving the public to suspend public or private social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, indoor and outdoor, including large social gatherings incidental to ceremonies, holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations, unless all participants are from the same household remains the same.    As of May 14, 2021, the following limits apply to gatherings in both public and private settings (for example, an event at a venue or a gathering at a home). If you don’t know if someone is fully vaccinated, then assume everyone is unvaccinated and follow that guidance.    For indoor gatherings:  There can be one unvaccinated person per 50 square feet up to 300 unvaccinated people (whichever is less), plus any number of fully vaccinated people.    For outdoor gatherings:  There can be 900 unvaccinated people, plus any number of fully vaccinated people.    If an event has no way of determining if an individual is vaccinated, assume all are unvaccinated for capacity limit.    All events and gatherings must also follow the Universal Guidance including spacing requirements and mask mandates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518025438/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043942/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/events-and-gatherings
notes_C4: Effective May 14, 2021, the following limits apply to gatherings in both public and private settings (for example, an event at a venue or a gathering at a home). If you don’t know if someone is fully vaccinated, then assume everyone is unvaccinated and follow that guidance.    For indoor gatherings:  There can be one unvaccinated person per 50 square feet up to 300 unvaccinated people (whichever is less), plus any number of fully vaccinated people.  For outdoor gatherings:  There can be 900 unvaccinated people, plus any number of fully vaccinated people.    If an event has no way of determining if an individual is vaccinated, assume all are unvaccinated for capacity limit.    All events and gatherings must also follow the Universal Guidance including spacing requirements and mask mandates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518025438/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/      https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043942/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/events-and-gatherings
notes_C5: As of May 11, 2021 closures of public transport detected.    Effective May 2, 2020 until further notice: Per the Governor’s Executive Order, all passengers riding public transportation in the state of Vermont will be required to wear a cloth face covering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518052136/https://vpta.net/blog/face-covers-required-on-all-public-transportation-vehicles-as-of-may-2-2020
notes_C6: As of May 11, 2017, there are restrictions and limits on social gatherings, but there are no stay-at-home orders. Vermont only advises citizens to stay at home if they are sick.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518053601/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/protect-yourself-others/prevent-covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043942/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/events-and-gatherings    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518023604/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations
notes_C7: Effective 9 April 2021, there is new travel guidance in Vermont.    Unvaccinated people must have a COVID-19 test within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.  - The test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).  - Proof must be presented of a negative test result.  - Quarantining does not exempt individuals from the testing requirement. They may choose to quarantine, but are still required to get a negative test before coming to Vermont.  - Vaccinated people do not need to get tested.    People who have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months do not need to test unless they develop new symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426172918/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/travel-quarantine/visitors-vermont
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of May 11, 2021, pandemic unemployment assistance and pandemic emergency unemployment compensation are available to certain citizens.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518060709/https://labor.vermont.gov/covid19/frequently-asked-questions
notes_E2: There are no changes. The temporary moratorium of natural gas, electric, and traditional landline telephone services and S.333 still remain in effect. Continue to code as 2.    Order extending the utility disconnection moratorium:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171543/https://documentcloud.adobe.com/link/track?uri=urn%3Aaaid%3Ascds%3AUS%3A73cb866e-627b-4bd0-b0ec-ee235c821509    S.333:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171646/https://legislature.vermont.gov/bill/status/2020/S.333
notes_H1: As of May 11, 2021, Vermont's COVID-19 public information website is still active.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518062356/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19
notes_H2: As of May 11, 2021, COVID-19 testing is accessible and free to the public.    There are still many testing sites across the state, these are available on an open public testing basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518062807/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/testing/where-get-tested
notes_H3: Continuing to code as 2 since contact tracing seems to be in place. However, as of May 1, 2021, contact tracing logs will no longer be needed for events and gatherings hosted by businesses and organizations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518063520/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/symptoms-sickness/close-contacts-contact-tracing    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518043942/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/events-and-gatherings
notes_H6: As of May 14, 2021, requirements for face coverings have changed depending on whether you have received the vaccine. The guidelines are as follows:  Requirements have changed effective May 14, 2021. However, it is important to remember that people with COVID-19 can spread the virus even if they don’t have any symptoms. Wearing a mask protects both you and the people around you from getting or spreading COVID-19.    If You Are Fully Vaccinated:  Anyone who is fully vaccinated is not required to wear a mask or maintain a 6-foot distance from others. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot.    There are some exceptions, and you will need to wear a mask in schools, health care settings, long term care facilities, correctional facilities and on public transportation. Businesses or municipalities can also require you to wear a mask if they choose to do so.    If You Are Unvaccinated or Partially Vaccinated (including children):  These individuals must follow the current mask requirements:    1. INDOORS: You are required to wear a face mask or covering in indoor public spaces in Vermont. Indoor public spaces include businesses, public buildings, and group living settings (such as long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).  In indoor private settings, we recommend that you wear a mask anytime people who are not fully vaccinated get together (for example, at a gathering with family and friends or riding in a car). Check the current limits on gatherings and events.    2. OUTDOORS: When you are outdoors, masks are only required when you are in a crowd or with multiple other households where you can’t maintain a 6-foot distance.    Vermonters can decide whether they need a mask by considering three elements:  •	Outside  •	Masked  •	Distanced    You need two of these three elements. For example – if you’re outside and distanced, you don’t need a mask. If you’re outside and not distanced, wear a mask. And if you’re not outside, you should wear a mask and keep a distance.    Masks are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for – and should not be worn by:  •	Children under the age of 2  •	Anyone who has trouble breathing  •	Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance  •	Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask    If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.    Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who are not wearing a mask, including people who are not required to wear a mask. However, the business must provide another way for people who are unable to wear a mask to access the business (for example, offering curbside pick-up or delivery or other creative solution).    The CDC requires everyone to wear masks when using public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518025438/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/
notes_H7: All Vermont residents age 12 and older are eligible to be vaccinated! College students and some residents of another state are now eligible for vaccines as well.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518065238/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/vaccine/getting-covid-19-vaccine

name: Washington
notes_C1: School re-openings are on a district by district basis with a plan for all schools to be fully open in the fall. As of now, different districts are in different phases with 2 districts still fully remote, others are bringing in different grades back to in person learning while the rest of the grades remain online while others are allowing students back in person but with the option to learn remotely depending on families' needs.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517121203/https://www.k12.wa.us/about-ospi/press-releases/novel-coronavirus-covid-19-guidance-resources/school-reopening-data
notes_C2: All counties remain in phase 3 except Cowlitz, Pierce, Whitman and Ferry that remain in phase 2. All counties are expected to move into phase 3 effective May 18.  Under phase 3, retail stores continue to operate at 50% max capacity with encouraged curbside pickup, professional services are encouraged to stay remote and personal services are to continue with an indoor max 50% capacity.  Under phase 2, retail stores continue to operate at 25% max capacity with encouraged curbside pickup, professional services are encouraged to stay remote and personal services are to continue with an indoor max 25% capacity    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517104334/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C3: All counties remain in phase 3 except Cowlitz, Pierce, Whitman and Ferry that remain in phase 2. All counties are expected to move into phase 3 effective May 18. Events include funerals and weddings, worship services, indoor and outdoor sports and entertainment establishments eg  Phase 3: Worship services are restricted to indoor max 50% capacity, weddings and funerals are to follow venue restrictions etc.  In phase 2, Worship services are restricted to indoor max 25% capacity, weddings and funerals are to follow venue restrictions etc.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517104334/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C4: All counties remain in phase 3 except Cowlitz, Pierce, Whitman and Ferry that remain in phase 2. All counties are expected to move into phase 3 effective May 18.  Phase 3 (indoor): Max 10 people from outside household  Phase 3 (outdoor): Max 50 people     Phase 2 (indoor): Max 5 people from outside household; limit 2 households  Phase 2 (outdoor): Max 15 people from outside household; limit 2 households     Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517104334/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C5: Most of Washington’s transit providers are still operating, many at reduced levels of scheduled service    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210510134408/https://wsdot.wa.gov/transit/home
notes_C6: No recent update on stay at home orders
notes_C7: For unvaccinated individuals traveling domestically, advice to hold off travel and stay home but if they must, in addition to wearing a mask, additional precautions were put in place during travel including;  -getting fully vaccinated for COVID-19 if eligible.  -Getting tested with a viral test 1-3 days before trip.  -Avoiding crowds and staying at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who did not travel with you.  -Getting tested 3-5 days after trip and staying home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel, even if test was negative. If not tested, then staying home and self-quarantining for 10 days after travel.  -Following all CDC travel requirements and recommendations after travel.    Fully Vaccinated individuals can safely travel domestically without need to quarantine or get tested but advised to follow CDC guidelines and wear masks in public, maintain 6 ft away from others and wash hands and use sanitizer.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517101227/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/Travel  Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517101449/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: As of May 10th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510003751/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: "Gov. Jay Inslee today announced applications will be accepted for the next round of assistance under the Washington COVID-19 Immigrant Relief Fund starting April 21.    The additional $65 million allocated by the Legislature this year will provide additional relief to support new applicants. Similar to the first round, the fund will rely on the continued partnership between the state and community organizations, including Scholarship Junkies and the Washington Immigrant Solidarity Network, with the Department of Social and Health Services providing oversight.     This round of funding builds on the governor’s prior allocations totaling $62.6 million for COVID-19 relief to immigrants in 2020, which provided much-needed assistance to nearly 60,000 individuals who were not eligible for federal COVID assistance due to immigration status. The fund coincides with other relief commitments by the governor in small business grants and rental assistance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210427184128/https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/washington-covid-19-immigrant-relief-fund-opens-new-applications
notes_E2: "Insurance Commissioner Mike Kreidler extended his emergency order directing all state-regulated health insurers to make additional coverage changes to aid consumers during the coronavirus pandemic. His order is in effect until May 30 and requires health insurers to:        Continue coverage for providing telehealth via methods including telephone and video chat tools such as Facetime, Facebook Messenger video chat, Google Hangout video, Skype and Go-to-Meeting.       Treat drive-up testing sites for COVID-19 as provider visits with no copay, coinsurance or deductible.    All medically necessary diagnostic testing for flu and certain other viral respiratory illnesses billed during a provider visit for COVID-19 will now be subject to coinsurance and deductibles starting May 2.     To help free up hospital beds, Kreidler is directing health insurers to waive or expedite prior authorization requirements for home health care or long-term care facility services to speed up discharging patients who are ready to leave."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502015810/https://www.insurance.wa.gov/news/kreidler-extends-emergency-order-telehealth-coverage-0
notes_H1: Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517113232/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/
notes_H2: There are several ways to get a test in Washington state. Depending on where one lives, they may have community-based testing sites, local clinics, and drive-thru sites offering accessible testing. Testing times can vary for a number of reasons, but many communities have more than one testing option. Testing sites can be found online for each county.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517094411/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/TestingforCOVID19  Link (testing sites): http://web.archive.org/web/20210517094530/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/TestingforCOVID19/TestingLocations
notes_H3: Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210415011509/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/ContactTracingInfographic.pdf
notes_H6: There are three public orders that combine to emphasize the importance of wearing masks and to encourage people to wear them in public places.    The workplace order: Washington employers are required to ensure workers are wearing face coverings at work in almost all situations. Employers must provide face coverings if workers do not have them; employers are responsible to comply with this order, and the Department of Labor & Industries enforces it.    The general public order: This order from the secretary of health requires Washingtonians, with some exceptions, to wear face coverings in public spaces (indoors in most situations, and outdoors when proper physical distancing can’t be maintained). People are individually responsible to comply with this order.    The governor’s order for customers in businesses: This order from Governor Jay Inslee says businesses cannot allow customers to enter their premises without face coverings. Other accommodations can be offered for customers who cannot wear masks. Businesses, with the help of local law enforcement if needed, are responsible to comply with this order.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517090528/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/ClothFaceCoveringsandMasks
notes_H7: As of May 10, more than 6,046,656 doses of vaccine have been given in Washington. More than 57% of people in Washington eligible for vaccine have received at least one dose and nearly 44% of people 16 and older are fully vaccinated against COVID-19.    As of May 12, Anyone in WA state that is eligible to receive the vaccine can now be vaccinated, regardless of where they live or work. This includes children 12-15 years old that have received authorization from FDA to receive the Pfizer vaccine that was already approved for anyone 16 and older.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514080539/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Newsroom/Articles/ID/2779/COVID-19-vaccine-distribution-update-from-the-Washington-State-Department-of-Health  Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210517093201/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/VaccineInformation/DashboardsandData
